The mastering of foreign languages, experienced geographic insights of different countries and cultures, the ability for planning and organizing events or trips, the readiness to work relatively independent, with pleasure for team work and communication, as well as the readiness for making further individual education efforts, has a favorable effect on the touristic sales conversation and the integration of the trainee into the labor market. This is the starting point of the project in mind. During the tourism workshop the trainees shall learn several hard and soft skills in the tourism sector. The objectives are learning Spanish - in closed group with a three-week intensive course by 20 hours/week and to get to know the Spanish tourism market better. Therefore sightseeing day trips to touristic meaningful places have to be developed and carrying out by the trainees. Three enterprises of the tourism industry have to be visited and interviewed. Another important aim is the training of intercultural competence. Here the intensive contact with the Spanish neighborhood, the teaching of the Sevillana dance, the joint cooking experience of Spanish cuisine shall contribute to this objective. During the workshop the vocational school subject of "Projects & Exercises" shall be tested in an extracurricular way in Spain. This is a general lesson involving many subjects. Particularly the subjects of "Business Processes in Tourism", but also communication in a foreign language and IT are involved. All results of the above described activities have to be written down and presented to an audience at the end of the stay. When the participation has been successful all participants will obtain the foreign language certificate of the Colegio Maravillas in the different levels according to standards of the European reference framework for foreign languages achieved previously and presented by the Spanish board of tourism. Furthermore the euro passport mobility and a participation confirmation of the OSZ Lotis will be handed over to every participant.

"Tourism Services" 
Tourism is one of the most important branches in economy. In future, its part and size are bound to get bigger. The success in tourism business field mostly depends on appropriately chosen and carried out policies. 
The world‘s tourism organization predicts positive development rates for Central and Eastern Europe. It is believed that by 2020 every third visitor will have attended these regions. 
One of the vital criteria in recreational services to ensure quality are professional labour resources. This is the main factor to provide recreational and other services. Business representatives responsible for organizing recreational services often lack management skills so there is much to be improved in training future professionals in Lithuania. Thus, there is a must to create opportunities for staff to refine and refresh their skills. 
Professional staff able to greet, accommodate, provide catering, entertainment and cultural programme are needed to satisfy the needs of tourists coming to Lithuania. Professionals able to provide the best services for people in Lithuania going abroad are also a need. Professional attitude results in satisfied customers and profit. Theoretical knowledge in tourism marketing and practical application of the marketing conception determines successful activity in this field. Students acquire skills and practice at school and companies during their practical training. Competent teachers are important to provide high quality education which satisfies the needs of labour market. Teachers need to refine their technological competencies not only in Lithuania but in foreign companies as well. 
Another important factor is development of sectoral practical training centres. 
The project is based on European dimension plan and strategic plan for the period of 2014-2015. It is planned to encourage vocational teachers to improve their technological competencies, creativity, innovative ideas and to ensure quality in practical training when opening a sectoral practical training centre in 2014, September 1. Business practice firm operating as a travel agency will be created so teachers will need sufficient knowledge and skills about providing travel and accommodation services and organizing active and passive recreation. 
The participants are 32 vocational teachers teaching recreational subjects and school authorities who are responsible for educational process. High requirements and challenges arouse when teachers try to pursue a higher quality of training. A teacher is involved in organization of practical training and in teaching-learning process. He/she is a competent and motivating advisor as well as the main source of ICT skills.  
The aim of the project is to satisfy the needs of participants to improve their qualification, the quality of educational process and make vocational schools more attractive. 
32 specialists from Klaipėda Tourism School, Šilutės Tourism and Business School, Panevėžio Trade and Business School and National Tourism Business Association, will be sent to foreign schools and companies to get introduced with preparation of staff working in recreation. 
The following results are expected. The specialists will improve their professional skills in Austria, Malta, United Kingdom, France and apply them in their job. 
The duration of the project is 12 months.
European College of Business and Management

Since 1999 we are conducting the project in London in cooperation with the „“European College of business and Management” (ECBM). We have established the project for the traineeship ‘Investmentfondskaufmann’ and we have been extending it to the benefit of our trainees who will become bank clerks. Having started with 40 participating students we are actually sending 60 students to London.

The title of the project ‘Banking centre London among the shades of the financial crisis’ clearly describes our aim: future bank employees should act faithfully and reliably on international financial places. During their stay in London the students should discover banking centre London with its severe problems. They should learn about British economy, banking centre London und British politics.  Visiting the docklands, the Bank of England and the stock exchange for example our students will make up their mind about London.

Target group of our project are ‘Investmentfondskaufleute’ and ‘Bankkaufleute’ who started their traineeship one year ago. They already passed their intermediate examination and went to vocational school on a block release. Their employers are mainly banks and investments funds companies in Frankfurt.

In London students mainly spend their time in college and getting to know the city as a financial centre. The college works out a training scheme tailored to needs of our students and is responsible for conducting the subjects. The lessons are held by native speakers. Excursions are also a part of the training program. At the end of the stay the students have to pass several exams to get 3 certificates. 

Early planning is very important for us: in September 2014 college, flights and hotel rooms have to be reserved. Booking the flight we also contract a travel cancellation insurance which covers the students’ own contribution of 650 €. For many years now we are guests of the Lancaster Hall Hotel in London and we stick to all of our partners that we are working now for many years. 

It’s our aim that students improve their professional, social, intercultural and linguistic skills. The following vocational and social competences should be expanded: the participants should discover the banking centre London and they should follow the college lessons about economic, political and cultural topics held in the English language. Furthermore they have to live and work with students of other institutions in an unknown surrounding. This requires a high level of social responsibility. The participants will get to know a foreign culture, because London itself is a melting pot of cultures. Going by tube to the college, going to museums is also a part of the students’ intercultural experiences in a very open and tolerant society. In discussions with their professors they will automatically think about the different strategies that both countries have to solve their problems. Since the dominant language in the financial sector is English  the students will gain professional and linguistic profit.
European College of Business and Management

The mobility project entitled " Doing Business in the Intercultural Environment" offers 20 participants of the OSZ 2 Spree -Neisse the opportunity to gain knowledge about the European economic and financial system and moreover to deepen and expand the foreign language skills. It offers the oppotunity for some teachers of our vocational school to deepen their knowledge about business and management and methods to teach it. The project is being prepared on OSZ 2 Spree -Neisse, will be carried out at the European College of Business and Management London over three weeks and evaluated after return.
In connection with this course, 20 participants create a project work in English whose theme is proposed by ECBM London or can be chosen by the participant in consultation with the training organization itself. Basically topics include dealing with the economic and social developments within the European Economic Area.
At the end of the stay, all participants will present their project work at ECBM London using modern media and pass a written examination on the taught subjects. The project work will be completed at home as executive summary and sent back to the ECBM London for evaluation.
After successful completion, all participants will receive at least two certificates. A certificate of German Chamber of Industry and Commerce in London (AHK London) and a certificate of participation by the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London on the topics dealt with .
In addition, any commercial participants may apply for and acquire the title of "Kauffrau/mann International" after successful completion of their professional training.
Each participant will receive the mobility pass. So they have better chances to work in business and to get a job because a good command of English is demanded by a lot of companies and institutions nowadays
The results of the project work will be presented at our school in English in classes of the relevant professional groups and serve as a basis for discussion.
Insights into the mobility project provide e.g. the publication of an online diary on our website, presentations to the staff of employers, the photo gallery in the school building , discussions at the European Week each May.
Meanwhile we have conducted four of such projects since 2010. The Mobility Project has become an integral part of our school programme and encourages many people in our region to consider Europe as an economic area and to take courage to be self- mobile.
European College of Business and Management

Context/ Background to the project: 

In cooperation with the European College of Business and Management, the Staatliche Berufsschule Ostallgäu (State Vocational School of the Ostallgäu Region) has planned and designed a three-week tailor-made training course for commercial apprentices. This course aims to enable interested students to complete a vocational, linguistic and cultural advanced training beyond the scope of their daily work and school life.



Aims of the project:

On the one hand, the course is aimed at improving the participants’ language skills in specific vocational and general topics. On the other hand, by providing them with an insight into the British economic capital, the apprentices will have a chance to widen their perspectives beyond their own/national experience and thus be more able to contribute to the development of the European community.



Number/Profiles of the participants: 

Every year, 22 young people, who are completing their first apprenticeship in different commercial professions, participate in this course. The students are aged between 17 and 20 years (depending on their educational background). As the participants are from different commercial courses, many of the group members first get to know each other during the four preparatory meetings.



Description of the activities: 

In a preparatory phase lasting approx. 6 months, the supervising teachers prepare the apprentices intensively for the training course during four preparatory meetings, in order to ensure productive work at the College. During the three-week stay in London, different lecturers from the College - together with the participants - will work on subjects in English, such as: presentation skills, business correspondence, the modern British economy, business ethics, corporate social responsibility, career development opportunities etc. During a three-hour exam in their third project week, the students will be tested on the knowledge aquired about the topics they have dealt with. In addition, at the end of the training course, the participants have to make a presentation in English about a previously chosen topic, which will be marked together with the summary that has to be handed in. Apart from school activities, the lecturers make various topic-related field trips together with the apprentices. Furthermore, two companies will be visited in order to gain an insight into the work environment of the financial centre of London. To round things off, guided city tours and visits to theatres and museums are offered as well. Despite the wide range of the course content, it is also important for us that the young people still have the possibility to explore the cosmopolitan city of London on their own and come to terms with a multicultural population. For this reason, the accommodation in host families – in a foreign-language environment – has proved itself to be very valuable.





Methods: 

It is agreed with the College that the three-week training course is instructed and accompanied by lecturers and supervising teachers. However, the participants have to complete their tasks independently and on their own responsibility.





Lasting advantages which can be expected by participating in this project:

1) Informing others in their company, school and private surroundings of the many impressions they have gained: these young people come back to their familiar environment with new and diverse experiences from abroad. In doing so, they pass on their impressions to their families, friends and acquaintances which leads to a widening of general interest. The companies feel encouraged in their active support when they recognize that their apprentices have improved noticeably in all areas. Thus, very often, new enquiries from the training companies regarding future projects arise only shortly afterwards. In school, the students present their project work to their classmates in English and thereby awaken their curiosity and earn additional respect because of their good performance.



2) Expansion of professional/personal perspectives: 

Experience shows that the young students returning from the three-week programme in London are more self-confident, balanced and motivated. In many cases, their attitudes towards other cultures have changed and their wish to have further experiences abroad has grown.



3) Increased professional/personal opportunities: 

Dealing intensively with cultural, linguistic and vocational matters in a foreign environment, the students who complete this course will gain new opportunities in their professional as well as in their private lives. Their improved foreign language skills, which can be presented to any (future) employer with the Certificate and the Europass Mobility, provide an undeniable advantage compared to other applicants. Many of the participants can imagine working or studying abroad in the foreseeable future. In terms of studying, the ECBM offers a Bachelor degree course.
Trainees compare work processes in Germany, Great Britain and Spain
European College of Business and Management

Our vocational training "Kauffrau / Kaufmann für internationale Geschäftsbeziehungen" (International Business Manager) addresses post A-level trainees with good and very good school grades and will focus on international economy, business and management, legal issues, book-keeping and communication. We aim to provide our students not only with the necessary key competences to participate actively in the European labour market but also with vital social skills to improve their personal development. We plan to have 16 students in our class.



We offer this vocational training because we intend to strengthen the employability of young people and to facilitate their transition to the labour market. It will improve our students' learning performance and their sense of initiative and entrepreneurship.



Tuition will be in German, English, French and Spanish, as we want to enhance the participants’ foreign language competences as well as their awareness and understanding of other cultures and countries. During the vocational training students will be able to acquire the certificate "Fremdsprachenkorrespondent Englisch" at the IHK in Dresden. 



The training will consist of theoretical instruction and practical periods. The practical periods will take place in Germany (7 months), Great Britain (3 months) and Spain (2 months). Students will have a lot of cooperation opportunities and will get to know working environments and processes in companies in these three countries. The students will be hosted at a workplace (either in an enterprise or an organization).



We make sure that the mobility periods abroad fit well with the course in general and will notably improve the participants' foreign language competences and enhance their cultural awareness. The main objective of the working periods abroad is to make students familiar with administration systems, structures and processes  in the receiving countries. We want them to compare different ways of working and living and to formulate their individual approch to issues and challenges in their working context.



Our objective is to offer our participants the opportunity to build networks of international contacts. They will also find out about cultural diversities and traditions and certainly develop a sense of European citizenship and identity. We also expect them to apply their knowledge from the theoretical phases of the training into the practical working environments in Great Britain and Spain. After their mobility period abroad, they will  be able to optimize administrative processes and to work more efficiently. 



In general, we expect our students to show increased self-empowerment and self-esteem, to participate more actively in society, to be more competitive and to show more mobility.



As regards staff, we expect a better understanding of practices, policies and systems in education and training in Europe as well as a greater responsiveness to social, linguistic and cultural diversity. We also hope that our teachers can improve their work and activities in favour of our apprentices and to promote mobility activities for learners to come. We are planning to develop more appropriate assessment and certification methods, based on the learning outcomes.



The representatives of Dr. Hirsch Akademie as an organisation are planning to increase their capacity to operate at an international level and to foster cooperation with partners from other countries. We would also like to expand our knowledge and expertise regarding the preparation, implementation, monitoring and follow up of projects.
European College of Business and Management

Participating in the first activity are the School of Horticulture Räpina / Estonia and our College of Further Qualification. We are linked by a long-time partnership within the framework of the LdV Programme Mobility in the first vocational training.  The participating trainee gardeners and florists work in Estonian companies, take part in school life and in landscaping the school’s and student hostel’s surroundings. Furthermore, they take part in professional competitions.
The project’s targets are getting acquainted with the Estonian world of work and professional training, the ecological features of the country, improving language skills and acquiring social competences. The project can only take place in the vegetation period, from May to September. Ten trainees per year take part. Their activities include: internships, school lessons, excursions, regional and cultural studies, joint leisure activities with the Estonian trainees. The participants are chosen and prepared in cooperation with their training companies throughout Thuringia, and they will stay in Estonia for 14 days. They are to write daily reports and design presentations about their stay which are presented to the training companies and their classes, or displayed in our school buildings.
Because the trainees in our vocational classes are from all regions of Thuringia (Landesfachklassen) they will share their foreign experience with their colleagues in the training companies of the whole Free State of Thuringia, which ensures a high degree of publicity for this project. 
The second activity is aimed at the students of the course of hotel management. The Ernst-Benary-School Erfurt and the European College of Business and Management London have been involved in this project for three years now. The two-week seminar is part of the international alignment of the two-year further qualification in business administration in the hospitality industry. When taking part in the PDP (Professional Development programme) of the London College they are in the second year of their further qualification at our school and they have already finished apprenticeships in various jobs of the hospitality industry.
The target of this project is the improvement of the participants’ language skills, especially in business communication, getting an inside of the British hospitality industry, and gaining theoretical knowledge about managing companies and leading people. The college offers a course certified by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce which is tailor-made to suit the students’ requirements. 20 students per your take part in this programme. 
Their activities include: lessons in English about the following topics: managing people, customer service, dealing with complaints, excursions to hotels and touristic highlights guided by the experienced teachers of the college.
European College of Business and Management

Project background
English is part of the curriculum for business management assistants (1 lesson/week). More and more trainees in the economy see themselves confronted with communication in English. With the rising globalization and internationalization we see the need to qualify our students for these challenges. This may work best in an authentic surrounding where you can experience and acquire new skills in a direct way. Above all, trainees who have not had the opportunity of being supported, i.e. especially not through European exchange programmes, should be enabled to profit from this project.
Learning outcomes
The participants are expected to improve their general and business-related knowledge of English during the 3-week-course at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. With the project-related work they shall be encouraged to work on their own, improve their presentation skills as well as develop team spirit – qualifications which are essential in a modern business world. 
Moreover, we want the participants to gain valuable intercultural experience, build up a healthy self-confidence and develop selfworthiness not only for their professional career. Closely connected we see the project as a door-opener to a positive attitude against life-long learning and minimizing internal barriers when it comes to work abroad.

Participants: Amount and Profile
The participants are 22 trainees for business management assistants in industry concentrating on the commercial side of the business. They have served about half of their apprenticeship of two and a half respectively three years already. They have a basic practical experience, a solid knowledge of English which mainly results from a secondary education, partly higher secondary or A-Levels. Their language skills are above average. Basic task-related vocabulary has been acquired at vocational school. There is also a basic knowledge of intercultural communication.

Activities/Implementation
The course at the ECBM includes lessons as well as group work on a chosen project (assisted by tutors). Their tasks also include research activities and a presentation which is part of the exam. This presentation has to be followed by a written executive summary. Furthermore, the participants have to pass a written examination. The cultural aspects include an overview on British politics, economy and society in lessons as well as excursions with the ECBM.
At a personal level the participants will be enabled to experience another culture, life in another household and host family, a totally new surrounding in a world city thus learning to understand, respect and accept other people. 
Their language skills will profit immensely not only from the stay at the college but the contact to and within the host families. The teachers from vocational school who will accompany and monitor the project will take them on cultural tours, e.g. tours of the city, visit museums, concerts, theatre plays and typical markets.

Results / Long-term outcomes
On the long run this project will help improve the participants’ intercultural skills as well as encourage them to see work abroad as part of their business life and accept life-long learning as an essential part of a professional career.
Fachspezifischer Trainingskurs für kaufmännische Auszubildende in Großbritannien
European College of Business and Management

The main aim of our project is to enable 24 students from the vocational school "Staatliche Berufsschule II Memmingen" to attend a three weeks course at the European College of Business and Management in London. The students, who train to be a bank clerk, industrial clerk or office clerk, are all in their second year of vocational training. During the course the students are able to improve their language skills in English as well as their knowledge in business administration issues.
At the college the students attend lessons every working day between 9.30 a. m. and 4.45 p. m. The lessons deal with topics which are related to their vocational training in Germany. The lessons are held by specially trained and experienced teachers from the college. In addition to the daily lessons, the participants have to write out an assignment on a special economic or social-economic topic, which is chosen by them individually. This as well as the final presentation at the end of the course, enhances the language skills immensely.
Next to the course, the students are obliged to plan and prepare several group excursions. The group leaders decide on relevant topics and talk them over with the students during the preparation meetings. The topics are then prepared in English by the student teams, so that they can be presented by them in London during the group excursions. 
One other major aim of the project is to enlarge the intercultural, social and individual skills of the students. They enter a new field with unknown cultural and social requirements, they learn to communicate and to cooperate with students and teachers. Their self dependent work on their projects and their excursion topics as well as the self-directed solving of problems increases their organizational skills considerably.
European College of Business and Management

IIn Germany, vocational training is mostly provided by German enterprises in cooperation with vocational schools. We, the Staatliche Berufsschule Eichstätt, are a vocational school with more than 1,400 students. The school is located in Bavaria, Germany. As more and more small and medium-sized companies, which are our dual partners, have transnational business relations they need internationally qualified staff. 



In order to meet the requirements on local, national and international levels our school is about implementing an international strategy in our school development programme. We aim to develop the skills of our students, to increase their employability and career prospects on the European job market and to modernise our education and training. 



A first step towards this goal is our mobility project in cooperation with the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. In 2015 we want to send 40 apprentices to the United Kingdom. The apprentices are part-time students who do an apprenticeship as a management assistant in retail business, in wholesale and foreign trade or office management assistants. In order to increase their business knowledge, intercultural experience and language skills the students attend an Intensive Course (PDP - Professional Development Programmes) that takes 3 weeks. In the courses they get an overview of British business and culture and an introduction to their specific areas of occupation and interest which can be built upon at a later stage. There are also excursions that have close relevance to the course topics. Their professional competences are developed through team work, communication and and oral presentations. During their stay at  British guest families and in London they gain insights in British life and culture and  improve their cross-cultural competence and understanding. After the course the students get the European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the German-British Chamber Certificate (AHK London). Moreover, after successful completion of their final exams of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK) in Germany they can acquire the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC), which is fficially accredited by the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce (AHK) in London. 



As we want to enable and support companies and students to establish and maintain international business partnerships it is also necessary to qualify our educational staff to organize and develop European mobility programmes and partnerships and to teach our students language and intercultural skills in a modern way. Thus, we also want to send teachers to the UK to do a training assignment or work placement at the ECBM or the German-English Camber of Industry and Commerce. During their stay some of them are going to monitor and accompany our students in London. 



The use of modern teaching methods and hands-on-learning in order to prepare all participants to work successfully and confidently in an international business environment is of high importance for the whole project. 



The success and quality of the project will be monitored and assessed with different instruments, e. g.  written and oral tests, feedbacks and questionnaires. Moreover, to  validate the competences acquired by the participants during their experiences abroad all participants get the Europass Mobility Document. They use and update their Europass Curriculum Vitae (CV) and the Europass Language Passport.

Doing Business in an Englishspeaking Environment
European College of Business and Management

Context / Background

In the background of economic globalization, it is important, in addition to academically trained to grant also people in vocational training foreign experiences to meet the needs of the world of work and the labor market. An - albeit short – stay abroad within the framework of vocational training shows the mobility of participants, their outstanding commitment and their raising employability.

Objectives

Goals, in addition to improving foreign language skills and professional competence, are mainly promoting self-confidence and initiative as well as the development of tolerance to other cultures and peoples. The described objectives meet the needs of ECVET and will be documented with the europassMobility and europassLanguage. A not unimportant side effect is that with the “Kaufmann International Certificate (AHK)” another formal certificate, an in Germany acknowledged document, will be reached.



Participants Group

The participants are all in initial vocational training in the dual system, or have completed the dual VET recently successful. The participants are recruited primarily from the professions bank clerks and industrial management assistants. Besides, also achievement-weaker find consideration.



Activities

In addition to schooling and language support, find self-regulated learning, working on economic issues with presenting the results as well as excursions to be held in London’s City based companies. The participants are nominated by training companies, which enjoy an excellent reputation for practical vocational training, but who see a clear need to improve the language skills of their trainees and future employees. In addition, a cultural program is offered with mandatory and optional elements.



The flows are planned for the following dates:

1. Flow: 19th April 2015 bis 09th May 2015

2. Flow: 04th October 2015 – 24th October 2015 



Intended results and impact

Measurable results in terms of the development of language competence should be able to be derived by the repeated self-evaluation by the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). With the increasing knowledge of the language and foreign experience itself the participants will be prepared to move well in an unknown environment which increases employability as well as their future chances on the labor market. The sending training companies can be sure to find an attractive and up-to-date programme in order to attract more potential job trainees. The awareness of Europe will also be strengthened as well.
European College of Business and Management

Since 2009, the Public Vocational School 2 in Passau conducts a 4-week stay abroad for the foreign language industrial business management assistants. In 2011, our school received a Leonardo da Vinci mobility certificate for this project. The mobility measure is a mainstay of our dual education and training model in the form of a double qualification as an industrial business management assistant and foreign language correspondent (English). This model is carried out in cooperation with the Chamber of Industry and Commerce of Passau and the regional training companies.

In accordance with the internationalisation strategy of the Public Vocational School 2, a four-member EU-Team consisting of teachers, who among other things organise the international project, was established in 2010.

The target group for this formal training and education are trainees with secondary school qualifications as well as high school graduates. By now, 30-40 participants take part in this foreign measure, each year.

We organise the stay in England as a combination of 2 weeks occupational project work at the European College of Business and Management in London, and 2 weeks work placement in small and medium-sized companies, organised by Tellus Group Ltd in Plymouth (South England). In a precisely designed training programme at the ECBM the aim is to especially promote the professional and linguistic skills of the trainees. During their work placement, the trainees work in international teams and correspond with foreign business partners, which in return, should encourage their intercultural occupational competence. Accommodating the trainees with guest families leads to improvement of their linguistic skills and a better understanding of the English way of life.

Due to a genuine encounter with a different culture, the entire stay leads to an awareness-raising and cultural openness of the participants. The relativity of values, perceptions as well as mentality and manners are sharpened. They have the ability to act appropriately in both professional as well as private intercultural situations.

At the end of each stay abroad, we have found that our trainees have become independent and self-confident and have reduced their fear of the new/unknown. The skills acquired through the project and certificates (e.g. Europass Mobility) improve the employment opportunities especially in international companies. Since 2008, in the course of this project, the offered training places for our education and training model have increased from 16 to 34 places. The success of this project was certainly one of the reasons why another vocational school in Lower Bavaria, the vocational school in Landshut, has decided to adopt this double qualification.
Teacher Development for Professional Purposes in Vocational Education and Training
European College of Business and Management

On this project teachers from commercial schools of Bayern, Nordrhein Westfahlen and Hessen have the possibility to attend a professional development for business orientated English and Economics in London. The participants teach English and Economics in dual commercial business apprenticeships and other schools. The training weeks are set up as ongoing one week programmes at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM).  The target of this program is to offer an in depth and current knowledge in the area of economics, to develop specialised language skills and to allow a comparison of the apprenticeship systems. Quality management and international networking are kept in focus. The teaching materials on this development programme are available to download from our own internet page. 

The training staff of ECBM as well as experts from the industry and educational centers has come together to develop a specialised training programme designed with the needs of our teachers in mind. Exclusively for this programme a professional Teacher Coach has been arranged to convey modern teaching and learning methods for the principles of teaching. Furthermore the training programme will include the following themes: the British educational and apprenticeship systems, the British Justice System, current political topics (such as the EU and Britain), economic topics (such as the property market, marketing, credit crunch, Banking system in England etc.) and the construction and the implementation of teaching material.

To support the theory discussed on this programme the teachers are taken to different economic institutions for example the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Metal Exchange, Bank of England, The Old Bailey, business companies etc.
 
One special advantage for the participants is the communication between colleges on a national and international level. Through this new cooperations are planned and new networks founded. In the context with international development programmes an intercultural exchange is especially important. That is why the participants are spending the training week staying at English host families. 

The project enables training unimpeded by national or international borders.

In 2014, 44 participants of the biennial and triennial (the students of the triennial course do a combined degree course of AVCE and State-certified Commercial Assistant for Foreign Languages) vocational course of State-Certified Commercial Assistants for Foreign Languages, 10 participants of the so called ‘dual educational courses’ ( Dual courses are a combination of theoretical vocational training at school and practical training in a company) of Personnel Service Providers, Insurers, Retailers, and 2 participants of the course of Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels will take part in the internship programme.
The Commercial Assistants who do their internship at the beginning of their last year of vocational studies then will have substantial demand of both, foreign languages in the field of commercial correspondence and terminology in foreign trade. They will have already obtained knowledge concerning such matters of commercial correspondence as enquiry, offer, order, delay in payment and notice of defects. Further, they will have learned how to handle different types of forms in the field of foreign trade and will have acquired detailed knowledge in the subjects of business administration, national economy and infonomics. In the latter they will have learned how to use computer programmes like Excel, Word and Powerpoint and will be well trained in word processing.
Due to all these skills acquired, they are qualified for working in international importing and exporting enterprises, shipping companies, international industrial concerns and organisations as well as in hotels and/or language schools.
At a time when their state of knowledge enables the trainees to deal with responsible tasks in a company or an institution, the internships offer the opportunity to link their theoretical knowledge with practical training. What concerns us primarily is that for teaching purposes didactically reduced case studies become verified in a real environment in order to enhance the students’ chances on the European labour market.
As this is a full-time vocational school training, the trainees have got few opportunities to work in side jobs to earn their own living. Thus, doing an internship in a foreign country does not only mean financial losses during the time of their stay but also considerable problems in raising the funds for a period abroad. Only if our trainees will be sponsored by the ERASMUS+ programme, we are able to realise our project.
Moreover, this programme constitutes the frame of security, trustworthiness, approval and professional advice and support which is so important to our partners and beneficiaries.
This year’s project of 8 to 11 weeks will be carried out in companies and institutions based in the UK, France, Spain, Malta, Ireland, Italy, Cyprus, Poland and Turkey. An internship of eleven weeks including the corresponding exam held and certified by a German-French board of examiners will be offered by the grammar schools Lycée St. Louis in St. Etienne and Lycée René-Cassin in Strasbourg.
With that the students are given the opportunity to get their practical skills certified and, thus, obtain a more favourable starting position on the labour market. For already two years now, we have been applying the ECVET instruments in co-operation with these partners. In recurrently held workshops we regularly update and adjust the instruments to the corresponding needs.
All details described above are mainly applicable to the Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks/A-levels, except the fact that these students are at the initial stage of their vocational training at the time of their internship. The trainees of the dual educational courses benefit from their three-week internship by testing their practical knowledge in other European countries.
The participants of the project will benefit considerably and sustainably, both, in their professional and private life from the improvement of their language skills, newly gained cultural insights and, last but not least, their personality development.
European College of Business and Management

In Germany apprentices have the right to be trained to get the skills required for a career in the envisioned business. This implies English language proficiency on the job. Especially industrial companies, logistics firms and companies in the whole sale trade need employees with these skills. They need that type of staff functioning effectively in a cross-cultural environment. Our vocational school (bsnu) cannot transfer those skills completely as the curriculum provides only 45 minutes per week to train our students in English language and cross-cultural skills. According to academic studies a native speaker of English can teach students, who learn English as a foreign language, more efficiently than an indigenous teacher. This course aims at improving our students’ professional competency as well as British culture and doing business in the United Kingdom.
The course is designed for 24 participants who are trained within the “dual system” of vocational training in Germany. We will only take apprentices who attend our school and work in companies which provide business orientated training in professions like industrial clerks, logistics clerks or wholesale clerks. Sometimes we have applicants from the retail trade or students who are trained in managing warehouses. Students at our school have an intermediate level of education or A-levels. Applying for our Erasmus+ project does not require A-levels. We recommend applying for participating in an Erasmus+ project of our school in the first or second year of their training because going to London in their final year may distract some students from preparing well for their exams carried out by the chamber of commerce and industry. A group of bsnu teachers and Sarah Iles from ECBM design a concept and the procedures of the new Erasmus+ project. We inform our students by handing out flyers and putting information about the project on the bsnu website. Our teachers inform their students about our planned project. We will send letters to companies which have taken apprentices to provide information about the project. When apprentices apply for participating in our project they must provide a written statement of their company showing they agree that their apprentice will be away in London for three weeks. After evaluating the application forms we will choose the participants. If a company indicates their apprentices require English and cross-cultural skills on the job in an extensive manner, those applicants will be put on a priority list. The advices and recommendations of the remaining companies and of bsnu teachers, who teach the applicants, will also be considered when choosing participants. In future we will not provide any English language courses for the participants. They can use online courses to improve their English proficiency. However, we will go on providing cross-cultural training and a specific training for the ECBM course in London. We will only send one group of students to London. According to our plans this will be in May/June 2015. Ms Yu Fengyan and Mr Albrecht Hofmann will accompany the group when travelling to London. They will stay with the group in London for three weeks and will join the group on their journey back to Germany. The accompanying persons will monitor the group and their learning achievements.  Ms Sarah Iles and the ECBM lecturers will be in charge of the teaching and motivation of the group while they are trained in London. After three weeks in London the participants can show in a presentation and in a written exam what they will have learned. After returning from London to Germany, the participants will have to write an executive summary in English (1000 words) about the topic which they presented as a PowerPoint presentation at ECBM. Our school will collect the participants’ documents and pass them on to ECBM in London.

Desired results:
better qualified staff
English proficiency
Improved business skills
international experience
self confidence, self esteem, adjusting to a new environment and a foreign culture
cross-cultural competences
new working methods and techniques

Impact and sustainable benefits:
improved communication skills with customers using English
improved career opportunities and opportunities for personal development
self confident and satisfied apprentices and future staff
more efficient, more profitable and more competitive companies
strengthen the economic region of Ulm and Neu-Ulm
more attractive vocational training opportunities in the Ulm/Neu-Ulm area
preventing a shortage of skilled professionals
Out of Rosenheim - Doing Business in Britain
European College of Business and Management

The principal objective of this mobility proposal is the further qualification of our  trainess through the consistent continuation of a strategy for internationalization at the Berufsschule II (vocational training school) in Rosenheim, Germany. It is our goal to continuously offer an increasing number of students in the departments of industry, banking and wholesale trade an opportunity to spend a part of their training abroad. Our partner, the ECBM London, offers a 3-week, intensive course at their college, at which our students may complete and earn the certificate of “international businessperson”. This certificate is awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London), ensuring that the qualifications and skills gained while abroad will improve the student’s chances in the job market and that the experiences abroad will have a lasting effect. 
We are starting the first flow which, in comparison to previous years, has an expanded group of participants, as well as extending the stay from two to three weeks. The special group of students who are participating in the double certificate program (industrial clerk and secretary with foreign languages) will be complemented in the first flow by motivated students in the 11th grade, who are from the industrial department. 

A selection process should ensure that students with good grades and who are motivated and cosmopolitan will take part in the project. The selection of the students will be cunducted in cooperation with the companies involved with the help of a letter of motivation, the Europass Curriculum Vitae and the  Europass Language Passport. 
In the following years, successive students and companies in the fields of banking and wholesale trading are to be approached in order to arouse the interest and readiness for completing a part of their internship abroad. These three commercial fields of interest offer a good curricular basis for interdisciplinary learning. 
Our English partner, the ECBM, is the training college for the German-British Chamber of Commerce. It was founded 22 years ago and is well established in the fields of basic and continuous training. The courses are tailored to our students. In Germany, the vocationally specific learning content is combined with English subject teaching and activity-oriented assignments and projects; traditional teaching forms are alternated with modern, activity-oriented forms. Additionally, factory tours are made to English subsidiaries of internationally operating companies, such as Siemens Crystal, BMW Oxford and FedEx. Excursions to the City of London enable the participants to gain a deeper insight into the British worlds of business and finance. 
 Our prospective industrial clerks (with or without the additional qualification for foreign language secretary) train in international companies and should gain job-related experience abroad as soon as possible, in order to be effectively successful in the future labour market. Gaining insight into international business processes and using English as the language of business are elements that give these students a professional and personal advantage. 
Another goal of the project is advancement of intercultural competencies, e.g.
• overcoming timidity to all that is foreign
• immersion into London’s intercultural society
• promoting tolerance and eliminating any possible prejudices
Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational education III

In our project are trainees of several programmes included. There are trainees, who are educated full time in school, we call them "Assistenten", the name of this kind of education programme is Höhere Berufsfachschule (HBFS), within this programme we have four emphases, these are Chemical technology (Chemical technicians), Biological technology (Biological technicians), Media design and information technology.

Additionally to the full time in school educated trainees we include trainees (mostly Biological Lab Assistants) out of the so called dual system.

The main topic of the project "Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational training III" is to provide opportunities to our trainees, who come almost out of the rural surroundings of our school, to make vocational experiences abroad in Europe.

We think that the young generation of the current trainees at the time of globalisation won't be able to stay for their whole professional life at home near their place of birth or their place of youth. They will have to be ready to join companies abroad, if they want to be successful in their jobs. In Sweden, as well as in the other countries where we are looking for options for internships, the trainees will meet foreign working cultures, which will not be common to them. They will learn to be a stranger the hard way, during their four week placements. We think this will help to develop broad-mindedness and acceptance for foreign people and cultures within their companies and living environment at home in the rural area of Marburg. Hopefully they will educate their fellow pupils in this way, when they are back from the four week internships.

The coaching of the students abroad will force us teachers as well. Our foreign language competences, especially our skills in using the technical language will increase by the communication with the instructors in the companies abroad. This will have positive effects not only to us but also to the pupils, who were not brave enough so far to do an internship abroad.
European College of Business and Management

1. Backround of the project:



The Kaufmännische Berufsschule IV sends students to the ECBM, located in London. These students work in the field of business administration and are involved in an international working area.

That´s why staying abroad would mean a lot to them, both for their professional and personal future. The project is run in two flows:

1st flow: 03 May 2015 - 23 May 2015

2nd flow: 29 May 2016- 18 June 2016



2. The aim of the project:



All participants are expected to improve their professional and social competences, their cultural awareness and also their language skills.



3. Number and profile of participants:



In each flow 23 participants from all different professional guilds take part.



4. Description of activities:



- Preparation

- Students are hosted by guest families and have to take part in school lessons at ECBM. 

- They will work in groups, doing Internet research while preparing a final project work dealing with a predetermined topic. 

- They participate in excursions and different cultural programmes. 

- In the end they all have to pass a final exam, which consists of 1. a written test, 2. an oral test and 3. a project work.

- Monitoring

- Evaluation



5. Methodology:



All participants have the chance to improve their above-mentioned competences and skills. They broaden their horizon by taking part in actively held school lessons and also by experiencing the everyday life in a foreign country. 



6. Results, long- term effects and benefits of the project:



- All participants get the chance to improve their competences and chances on the international labour market.

- Companies benefit from training of their human resources.

- The local area remains competitive as compared to international standards.

- The unemployment among youth can be reduced.



7. ECVET - Europass Mobility, Europass Language Passport, Europass CV and Certificates



- Learning agreements with all students and signed by all partners

- Europass CV, Language Passport and Mobility for the students to document the Mobilty Activity

- the students get also further certificates to document the activities by the ECBM and the German-British Chamber
GoEurope - wir bringen Berliner in Bewegung: Mobilität für Auszubildende, Berufsschüler, Absolventen der beruflichen Bildung, Referendare und Berufsbildungsexperten.
European College of Business and Management

15.7 % of all youths in Berlin are currently unemployed - considerably more than most regions of Germany. This difficult situation leads to the most essential goal of our project: improving the employability of young apprentices, students in vocational schools as well as recent graduates. We intend to achieve our goal by offering high-quality, custom-designed stays abroad for these youths - directly related to each participants' individual vocational background. We will collaborate with numerous vocational training centers in Berlin, the participants' training local companies as well as with the Chambers and the unions. Additionally we will improve the "European competence" of stakeholders in vocational training and other local institutions through knowledge transfer and will institutionalize this process by integrating these players into our project as project partners. On another level we intend to improve the social integration of participants who are young parents, have a migrant background or are disadvantaged learners.

The following are the two MAIN activities we will offer the youths mentioned above:

- internships abroad

- project work abroad related to participants' vocational field 

Most of the participating youths will be from the following fields: clerical occupations, media, hotel, gastronomy, carpenters/joiners.

These main activities will supported by the following FLANKING activities offered to professionals  from vocational training centers in Berlin: 

- Preparatory Visits abroad (e. g. to prepare mobility flows)

- Training for professionals covering the topics 

o „The European Job Market – a challenge for local vocational training centers?“ 

(also for professionals with a lower foreign language proficiency level, 4 day course)

o „European Training and Instructing Traditions - Learning from the Best in the Field“ (for professionals with a higher foreign language proficiency level, 7 day course)

Further FLANKING activities will be offered to student teachers in Berlin:

- „Improving the European and Mobility competence in teacher training“ (7-day course)

Our GoEurope mobility network encompasses 40 different partner organizations in 17 EU countries  plus Turkey. All of our partners are specialized in the professional execution of Erasmus+ (formerly Leonardo-da-Vinci)-funded internship and project-work stays abroad . Most of them can draw on a network of hundreds or more internship companies. They are well connected with the vocational training centers and political institutions  in their respective regions. 

As soon as the decisive parameters of a mobility flow have been defined together with the local training institution the project is actively promoted to the defined target group. As soon as the participants for a particular flow have been secured the partner organization in the host country is commissioned with carrying out the preparations for the flow. The quality of each flow is ensured by a number of measures, e. g. mid-term reports, evaluation meetings, accompanying visits and/or a preparatory visit. 

The desired outcome of the stay abroad is always to improve the participants' employability (roughly 10 % of our participants even receive a job offer abroad), improved social integration of participants who are young parents, have a migration background or learning disabilities, improved proficiency in foreign languages as well as personality development. Furthermore, we intend to create excitement for the European Union in general amongst satisfied participants! All of them can be instrumental in internationalizing their educational institutions. Particularly by helping to create a functional network between the body responsible for the project and local partner organizations. 

Our network has been growing for nine years now and the long-term effects of our steady growth in terms of quality and numbers of participants are becoming ever more evident. By now 15 Berlin vocational training centers have already appointed an EU-Affairs Representative to manage their collaboration with us. Two vocational training centers now even offer vocational training courses with integrated mobility stays abroad. For our EUROPASS mobility ceremonies we are often honored to have undersecretaries of state personally handing over the certificates to our proud young participants.

A development towards an innovation and internationalization cluster including our local, national and international partners is becoming ever more visible. Junior and Senior Management as well as EU-Affairs Representatives are exchanging experiences and inspiring each other in their efforts towards enhanced employability of the youth.

Last but not least close to 500 youths come back home - excited about their mobility experience abroad. They have gained personally - an experience they will be able to draw on during their whole (professional) life. We intend to continue down this road of enrichment in the new Erasmus+ program!
European College of Business and Management

This project is implemented by the Städtische Berufsschule 4 Nürnberg (abbreviated below as 'B4') in cooperation with the European College of Business and Management (abbreviated below as 'ECBM'). It is an important part of the B4's internationalisation strategy. This strategy is intended to prepare B4's students for changing requirements of the labour market which are due to the increasing internationalisation of the German economy. Since many local companies are very export-oriented (Export rate in the region is 45 %, according to the Chamber of Commerce), they need more and more employees who are familiar with international business practices in addition to business English skills. The willingness of employees to occupational mobility is also becoming increasingly important.
The main objective of this programme is to improve the participants' career prospects by increasing their knowledge of international business practices, communication and foreign language skills. The course enables them to obtain the "Kaufmann International Certificate" certified by the Deutscher Industrie- und Handelskammertag (DIHK). The target group of this project are VET learners in companies. The B4 will send a group of 25 commercial trainees to London. 
The aim of the project is to enable the participants to understand international business practices in the context of the European economic area by using the example of London as an international financial and business location. Furthermore participants can improve their knowledge of English and intercultural skills.
During this three-week programme important skills such as telephoning, business correspondence, negotiating and applying for a job in a foreign language are trained. The students learn how to plan, implement and present projects in English in an international environment. The project work also stimulates their intercultural awareness, helps them to develop their personality and willingness to occupational mobility .
The B4 has established a special team for planning and implementing international projects, which is called Europateam. It ensures the sustainability and quality control of  these programmes. All participants give us feedback before, during and after their stay abroad by using an online questionnaire. The questionnaires are evaluated by the Europateam. Therefore we are able to update the content of this programme in close coordination with the ECBM and to meet the needs of our participants. 
We expect  improved  employment opportunities for the participants of the programme due to the Kaufmann International Certificate and an increase in their occupational mobility.
European College of Business and Management

SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL are mobility programme for trainees. The programmes are being conducted by sequa and commenced operation in September 2008. SINDBAD is an European Mobility Programme for trainees; TRANSDUAL is a Mobility Programmes for trainees who intend to untertake practical and theoretical learning either in Madrid, Paris or London. Soft skills like mobility, flexibility, tolerance and capacity for teamwork become increasingly important in the labour markets. The programmes' targets are to supporting the development of these soft skills. SINDBAD and TRANDUAL targets are to gain professional experience on international level. SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL are being funded by the LEONARDO DA VINCI programme. LEONARDO DA VINCI, itself, is the non-academic mobility programme within the LIFE LONG LEARNING Programme (LLP) of the European Commission. sequa´s  role is to file the application and to administrate the funds. 

484 mobility flows shall be implemented in the project period 2014 - 2016.



Mobility of Vocational & Educational Institutions and Trainers (move-it) is sequa’s mobility programme dedicated to the vocational education and training professionals. Since June 2012 the programme is conducted by sequa in cooperaton with partner organisations. move-it is financed by "VETPRO - Vocational Education and Training Professionals", a sub-programme of the European Commission’s Leonardo-da-Vinci programme. 

108 mobility flows shall be implemented in the project period 2014- 2016.



Both mobility programmes are “pool projects” and the respective flows for participants are published nationwide and accessible for anyone who fulfills the application criteria. Thereby individuals whose trade training institution has not applied for mobility projects do also have the possibility to participate in the EU Erasmus+ programme

Our mobility project for job-seekers within the framework of Erasmus+ takes into account ten principles of the European quality commitment for mobility. 

The regional council of Basse Normandie is widely supporting this project since it answers to its strategy of openness towards Europe and the world. The Region wishes to develop its international exchange programmes and especially company internships in Europe to allow job-seekers to get a faster occupational integration (80 % during the last programs). By bringing its financial support to this project, the French Region of Low Normandy shows its interest and its will to collaborate in the placement of job-seekers



A Steering committee that consists of an executive of Pôle emploi Basse Normandie, representatives of the French Region Low Normandy and advisers of the PEI ( International Employment Agency), determines a protocol of implementation concerning the choice of countries, the contents of the stay in host countries, the administrative aspect (social welfare) and the remuneration for the trainees, the selection of the partners and the participants, the financing of the program, the follow-up of the action, the qualitative and financial balance assessment.



This program is directed by the contractor which leans on sending partners and host partners based in European countries. The host partner is appointed by the contractor to build-up a real network of local companies interested in the European mobility of the workers and presenting the need for staff. There are several companies interested in receiving interns. Thanks to 19 years of European experience, we benefit from a wide network of companies in most of the European countries, facilitating the placement of the trainees. 

Regular contacts between the various partners, the beneficiaries, and companies will facilitate a continuous monitoring of the project.



Individual and group evaluations will allow us to measure the gap between the initial project and its realization. 



Living and working in another country of the European Economic Area will allow job-seekers to:

• Better match the needs of companies, to strengthen their professional and linguistic skills in a different professional environment 

• Discover new techniques, new fields of experience, 

• Know new cultures and another way of company organisation  

• Become integrated as soon as possible within the European labour market, 

• Develop new employment prospects, 

• Be more autonomous. 



Moreover, this project allows young job-seekers to live a first work experience in Europe in a context where job offers target only experienced people. This type of programme is often the response to their integration preoccupations. A mobility experience is a real asset to build employment pathway in Europe. All sectors can be concerned. The potential beneficiaries will be informed through posters in the different employment areas (Pôle emploi, local missions, youth areas,…) during employment forums an through www.pole-emploi.fr.



We will specifically target job-seekers with level IV diploma that didn’t already benefit from a training course in Europe and that know some occupational integration difficulties. 



The French Region Low Normandy participates financially in this programme and allows the participants to have the intern in vocational training status so they can obtain remuneration during these 9 weeks. 

In their return, the candidates will have to write a report and will get a certificate of internship in complement to the EUROPASS. A final balance assessment will be realized by the contractor and send to all our partners and financiers.



The intended impact of this project is to get an occupational integration of the targeted public. Indeed, this immersion in a company will be a determining factor in the professional evolution of the candidates. It will allow either integration in the host country, or additional assets for an occupational integration back in France.

The impact of this program also concerns the interest of the politics to participate to this kind of action, to build a partners' network specialized in candidates' reception.



This year, countries aimed by this program are: Germany, Spain, Ireland, Italy, Malta and the United Kingdom.
Mobilité et rayonnement de la classe euro logistique 2014

This project is aimed at 12 pupils having registered in the three-year baccalauréat professionnel logistics course. At this point these pupils have also attended a European course for two years.
      
       This project answers the specificity of the course for many reasons: 
                
                  1 –The activities linked to Logistics are bound to be European and even international. Delivering, storing, carrying goods from one point to another imply that companies must work with their European counterparts. Furthermore, in a globalized world, they will have to work with partners all over the world if they want to remain competitive. Many of them in Essonne, already work with partners in Eastern Europe, Portugal, Italy, Spain , the USA or Brazil among others.
                 
                  2 – Some of our students have already worked in international companies like Rungis and they know about the situation. Professionals from the Southern industrial area near Paris where most of our students are from, welcome our students from European classes. They fully understand the importance of being able to communicate in and to master English. Consequently, the opportunity to perform a training period in an English-speaking country is of the utmost importance.
                  
                   3 – The geographical situation of our lycée added to its specificity: Lycée des métiers de automobile et de la logistique, totally justifies our desire to perpetuate this type of project.
                   4 – The confirmation, with the previous experiences abroad, that it brings a lot to our students on many different levels: 
                          - Linguistic: They gain a confidence that allows them to feel that they are able to communicate in English. They ask questions to people their age but also to older people and  to professionals. After spending five weeks in London, they no longer   fear being judged for their English skills and they are able to express themselves freely.  
                          - Academic: After acquiring this self- confidence, they now feel like they can succeed. Academic success is no longer reserved to pupils from Lycée general but it is also attainable for pupils from vocational schools who  make an effort and who are willing to take risks. As a result, they are more motivated and  more willing to attend school, to work and ready to make stronger efforts.
                            - Personal: This project helps our students to mature and to gain an entrepreneurial spirit and to achieve greater autonomy  which are highly valuable skills demanded by most companies. This program also helps our students to develop a greater sense of acceptance towards people of differing racial, ethnic, generational, sexual and religious backgrounds.
                               - On the labour market: Our students will be employed more easily and they will be more willing to work abroad and to share their skills with other companies.
                         In companies, they are expected to be able to:
                                 - Receive and store goods
                                 - Prepare and ship orders
                                - Welcome drivers on the telephone or in person
                                 - Understand written documents.
     
             They will be supervised by the school partners,the project partners (the families and the companies), and the members of the CEI.  Meetings, telephone calls, mails, social networks, videoconferences will be used to manage, communicate, cooperate, monitor and assess the mobility program. The students will be accompanied by the English teacher who will make sure the families and companies live up to the  personal and professional expectations (professional task in keeping with the school curriculum). The DNL teacher will fetch them and assess their training period with the tutor.
     

        Long-term benefits are numerous:

        1 - Our school will become more attractive and will be better known thanks to the activities linked to the mobility program. For example we have recently updated our school website to inform about the "classe euro et sa mobilité",the Journal de Savigny will publish an  article. The school "Open Day", the French families feedback, the meetings with all the members of the school and the students of the mobility, the graduation ceremony, the meetings with the alumni who tell about their professional and personal experience, play a large part in the widening of our school.
       Our regular contact with the CEI,  already very well-known and specialized in jobs and internships placements, and accommodation for individuals and groups ,  also helps us be more influential in the future.
 
        2 - Our students in higher education

        3 - Our students in the European and International labour market. 

         4 - A stronger sense of  citizenship  among our students
De Bonneville à Londres : l'engagement vers une ouverture européenne

Guillaume Fichet secondary school offers  all courses including a vocational section. It is situated in the centre of a town of  slightly more than 12 000 inhabitants.

Our goal is to show that the creation of a European section (in September 2011) develops  our students’ambitions and skills for a better vocational guidance. We wish to regurlaly send students to London, England for a 4 week internship in January, the goals being :
- To develop our students’s well being, self esteem and self fulfillment
- To increase their confidence and autonomy at school leading to improvements in their academic results for the rest of the year and a better success rate on their BTEC national and in their daily life
- To take more initiatives 
- To improve personal and business linguistic skills
- To learn how to manage a budget
- To promote the desire to return to London on their own initiative 
- And to become more reliable citizens  
This year, 9 students have joined the European section. The mostly come from an underprivileged social backgroung and 40 % of them have poor academic results.
They are motivated but some are introverted and lack self confidence.

During their training period in London the students work in different shops and are  supervised by  internship tutors.
Their main activities are : welcoming and informing the customers, working at the till, preparing the items (clothes, shoes, jewelry, accessories, books, homeware...) and resupplying, stock managing, displaying the items and implementing the shop window, maintaining and cleaning the shopping area and finally managing the banking documents. We signed a partnership document with the shops involved.

Our students currently receive 2 weekly extra hours of study, one of European English (improving linguistic skills) and one hour of professional English (learning professional vocabulary). Those 2 hours strengthen the administrative, professional, cultural, educational and psychological preparation of the students for their internship in London.

This project will  have 5 different impacts :
• Locally, the press that promotes our project
• Regionally, by the documents we send  back to them, signed by the partners (indicating the regional grant was well used),
• Nationally, (the BTEC national success rate and evolution of our school's ranking)
• In  Europe  (proof that the European grant  has been used for our students’training and performance)
• Regarding future job opportunities ; our students may have greater success securing an internship abroad

Not only do our students become aware they must surpass themselves to optimally prepare  their training period, but, it also acts as  a springboard and  a new beginning for their academic and personal life.
Nowadays we are more and more focused on international exchanges.

Thanks to sending of students to London and all the preparation that entails, our team of 3 teachers will remain intellectually challenged. Our students will always benefit from the experiences, work and motivation of their teachers.
European College of Business and Management

The project "economy in comparison" is designed to motivate young business students at the C.G. Zimmermann Handelsschule to broaden their interest and perspective. In order to deal with an international economy and global world in an adequate manner the students are asked to be engaged in the economy of Great Britain.

Furthermore the project will help the students participating in vocational education at C.G. Zimmermann Handelsschule to improve their foreign language competencies. Great Britain is selected as partner country of the project "economy in comparison" as the ability to speak the English language is an important precondition of successfull career bracket in the field of economy. Furthermore the choice of the British partner points out the importance of the British economy and finance.

With regard to didactic high value is set on autonomous learning - students will acquire relevant knowledge and insight within the project by themselves.
