- Improving the quality of the training, delivered in the school, and adapted to linguistic, social and cultural diversity. This will allow schools to meet disadvantaged people’s needs in a more efficient way and to understand better what active European citizenship is.
- Improving knowledge and the use of evaluation and certification tools (ECVET and EUROPASS). 
- Increasing the attractiveness of vocational training education, to make it the first selected option for students and enhancing the prestige of the participating VET schools.

The project is strictly related to the 2020 Strategy and the New Skills Agenda for Europe 2016; it is consistent with the strategic priorities for contributing the increase in employment, productivity and social cohesion in the EU and its member states.
Work based learning in Europe for more and better jobs and a fair and open society

Considering the labour market’s functional changes and its modernization, as well as the very high youth unemployment rate (more tan 50%) and the dropout rate among VET students without any professional qualification, educational systems are clearly facing the challenge of improving student’s professional improvement, incrementing their participation as active citizens in the society, and their employability inside and outside the European labour market.
The project aims at providing VET students with the chance to deepen and improve the quality of their training, by carrying out internships in European companies, and getting in contact with European labour market. 
The close cooperation among the VET Schools that are members of the consortium, set the basis for the development of this project.
The consortium is composed by 9 VET schools of the Valencian Region, coordinated by the IES Ramón Esteve.
The consortium VET schools need to establish European quality networks with companies and other educational centres throughout Europe, in order to stay update on innovations, to share good practices and to get informed on European policies, improving the quality of the provided teaching and trainings, thus fighting youth unemployment. 
The project is addressed to former students and students who are attending the 2nd course of school-based intermediate VET programme in Computer Science and Communication, and Administration, or to former students just graduated, i.e. technicians in the above mentioned professional sectors. 
The project foresees the participation of 72 VET students, distributed in 8 flow: 4 to Italy, 1 to Portugal, 1 to Latvia and 2 to United Kingdom. Each centre will select 2 former students (technicians) and 6 students.
It is worth mentioning that relations with the European partners fostered reciprocity, as all the participating transnational centres has also submitted a mobility project in which Spanish consortium will receive their students. The reciprocity will enhance the promotion of the European active citizenship.
The 1 year project will last from the 1st of July 2017 to the 30th of June 2018. The internship will be carried out from the 15th of March to the  30th of May 2018.  
The following activities will be structured in 5 phases:
E1- Activities for communicating and spreading information to promote the students’ participation, planning tasks (including participants’ selection), establishing Learning Agreements, reviewing of ECVET documents, logistics and organization (insurance, lights and accommodation), determining contract-related issues, selecting hosting companies, tutors and accompanying teachers, setting up a common dissemination plan.
E2-Preparation of the mobilities. Information Meeting, signing contracts, linguistic, cultural and professional preparation, OLS registration for students.
E3- Implementation of mobilities. Follow-up, evaluation and certification of participants. Competences will be determined in the Learning Agreement and will be evaluated, using the ECVET instruments and will be certifies by Europass. 
E4- Quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the overall project’s results.
E5- Dissemination. The dissemination activities will be carried out throughout the project’s duration. An extraordinary staff meeting will be held in all the consortium centres. A Final Conference will be also organized.
In addition to the impact on the participants, the project will also benefit all the partners, by fostering  European cooperation and the relationships between companies and educational centres. 
Both dissemination activities and the mobility experience itself will produce an impact at local, regional and national level. 
Other local, regional and national entities will be able to to benefit from the project’s results (even though they are not partners of the project):
- Creation of a quality network that include educational centres and companies
- Decrease in youth unemployment rate
- Improvement of youth qualifications
- Increase in VET enrolment 
- Creation of new collaborative networks at regional level
- Widening the possibility of internationalization for other centres, and their chance to be part to other European projects
- Better knowledge of the Erasmus+ programme and EU values (tolerance, equity, equality and inclusion).
- Fostering the sense of European active citizenship and respect of other cultures
- Possibility to create new companies and new business models 
- Promotion of social inclusion
The project is in accordance with the Strategy 2020, the New Skills Agenda for Europe 2016 and the Erasmus+ objectives, improving the professional development of the students, their participation as active citizens in society and and their employability inside and outside the European Labour market

More than 35% of students regret within one year their job or choice of studies. Students often don't know what they want or don't know their options. They go through an unclear orientation phase and decide at the last moment. Drop-out rates are extremely high.  Students in vocational training are confronted with a professional choice that doesn't suit them at all.
All these students need better guidance regarding  their possibilities. As a school we have the responsibility to support them during this process. students should be able to testdrive the sector of their choice during an internship in different working situations. This helps students to asses the different aspects from their future professional life.
During internships new compettences will be developed. Students experience companyculture and learn to cope with the demands of employers. They learn to engage actively in their own future.
The feedback from both participants and workplacements are invaluable for the school itself to evaluate their own programs, but also for the function it has as a job-orientation counselor. Accompanying persons can spot new trends, technologies ad practices and bring these new ideas back to the school.
On a yearly base students of the program 'managing and undertaking' get the opportunity at a 2 week internship in companies in Londen. Students of industrial cooking of the fifth year undergo  a cooking internship in Greece. Students of the sixth year get the opportunity to go to the far North, Norway.

The seminar organized by Amaro Foro e.V. will bring together 40 Roma and non-Roma multipliers and youth activists from 11 European countries (Germany, Macedonia, Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, Estonia, United Kingdom, Turkey, Italy, Austria,France, and Spain) aims to develop a comprehensive approach on the issue of Genocide remembrance and education of marginalized youth, their effective involvement and participation in local, national and international programmes, to strengthen cooperation and relations between Roma and non-Roma youth and youth organizations in order to strengthen the conceptual understanding for inter-cultural dialogue, youth inclusion, empowerment and mobilization, as well active citizenship and to establish a support system for enhancing Roma youth capacities and developing new projects within the new Erasmus plus Programme. Moreover, the project will look into practices and methods for youth inclusion and empowerment among youth organizations in addressing and fighting discrimination, racism, xenophobia, especially antigypsyism as a modern form of racism towards Roma and help developing a collective memory of remembrance and commemoration by raising awareness about the 7Holocaust and Roma genocide during WWII. The 8 days seminar "Nothing about us, without us!"will take place on December 1-8, 2017 in Berlin, Germany representing an opportunity for young people that are capable of addressing human rights issues in grassroots, national and international actions. 
The seminar aims to strengthen the coordinated efforts of building joint initiatives on grassroots level, as well as on international level towards the commemoration and to challenge antigypsyism and racism in Europe. This project will not only increase the knowledge and sensitivity of the young Europeans on the topics, but the increased awareness of the young Roma and non-Roma can strengthen the consciousness of the participants about their role and responsibility within their communities, the society and in Europe at large. Strengthening cooperation between young Roma and non-Roma, and different youth and human rights organizations will be another step in building the collective historical memory, awareness and respect for human rights and impulse to a wider official recognition by European countries of August 2nd, as a day of commemoration of the Roma Genocide during World War II. April 15, 2015 marked a historical moment, The European Parliament voted with an overwhelming majority to finally adopt a resolution which recognizes “the historical fact of the genocide of Roma that took place during World War II” and concludes “that a European day should be dedicated to commemorating the victims of the genocide of the Roma during World War II.” Of huge importance is the fact that this resolution also “underlines the need to combat anti-Gypsyism at every level and by every means, and stresses that this phenomenon is an especially persistent, violent, recurrent and common place form of racism.”

Young people EVS 7 is an Erasmus + European Voluntary Service project. Malta, Portugal and Italy. The project application was prepared by the Turkish National Agency according to the coordinator organization.

Our main goals and main focuses in these activities are as follows.

In our project, volunteers will receive assistants to the qualification staff and actively participate in the development of the professional development program. The selection of the volunteers will be made by consultation with the relevant staff. Volunteers can plan their own activities if they wish, and creative ideas are welcomed and made by all partners. They will receive volunteer language training in the project. Language training is a practical speech conversation everyday. Volunteering times were arranged together with the host organizations. The host organizations will primarily see the motivation letters of the volunteers and then decide. It is your responsibility to volunteer at the criteria required by the sending organization's host organization.

The target mass of the projects is generally disadvantaged youth, and at the end of the project, these young people are planning to improve themselves and culturally develop their employability. Projects aiming at international mobility and social awareness in the short term, fold in the floor in the participation of youth.
Übergang von der beruflichen Ausbildung in die Arbeitswelt
European College of Business and Management

In our two previous projects the participants compared the processes of personnel planning and personnel recruitment in Germany and in our partner countries.

Project A:
In our new project the emphasis will be on the transition from vocational training to employment and its requirements and challenges.

The students will do an internship for 3 to 4 weeks in our partner countries (Poland, Finland and Spain) and have to identify requirements that job starters have to meet, but also obstacles and challenges that both companies and job starters have to face. The students will hopefully gain new qualifications and knowledge, get prepared for the international job market but also reflect and analyse their own competences and skills.

In a second step, the participating teachers will do a job-shadowing week in our partner schools and should get an overview about the skills, competences, professional knowledge and key qualifications that are being taught during the students' vocational training. They will then compare those with the students' findings and deduce recommendations for action and good-practice-examples.

The project assignments will be as follows:
Students' project assignment: identifying typical tasks and activities of job starters, required qualifications, support measures and activities of the company (e.g. mentoring, introductory weeks, seminars) as well as obstacles and challenges. They should compare those results with their own experiences (self-reflexion).

Teachers' project assignment: identifying the skills, competences, business knowledge and key qualifications that are being taught during the students' vocational training as well as the measures to prepare the students for entering the international job market (internationalisation strategy of the school). Desirable would also be results and findings concerning the preparation for the job market of disadvantaged groups (refugees and inclusion). Since our school has started with CLIL (Content and Language Integrated Learning) lessons last September and our Spanish partner school has already been practising CLIL for several years an exchange of experiences concerning that topic is planned as well.

The results of both students and teachers will then be used to answer the following question: "In what way does the vocational training prepare the job starters for the requirements of the professional practice/the job reality?" The results will then be translated into guidelines, recommendations and good-practice-examples.

In the near future a cooperation with an Italian school is planned. Contacts with an Italian school have already been established and will be further intensified.

Project B:
Besides the mobilities of project A the school will also send 20 students per year to the European College for Business and Management in London. The students will take part in a three-week professional development programme (PDP). The business courses will be held in English and focus on international business and finance, but also Business English and international competences. After completing the PDP course the students can apply for the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC). It will be awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London), which operates under the umbrella of the German Association of Chambers of Industry and Commerce (Deutscher Industrie- und Handelskammertag, DIHK Berlin). Certificate holders prove that they are able to operate in an international business environment.

Both projects will underline and support the internationalisation of our students and will provide them with the professional and personal qualifications, skills and knowledge necessary for being able to compete on the international job market in a further together growing Europe.
European College of Business and Management

The majority of young people in Germany are trained in a scheme which is called „dual system“. During their training they are employed by companies which train them on the job. On one or two days of the week the young people, who are called apprentices, attend a vocational school. They are eligible to be trained in order to get those skills required for a career in the envisioned business or trade. This implies to acquire English language proficiency on the job. Especially industrial companies, logistics firms and companies in the whole sale trade need employees with these skills. Companies and employers need that type of personell functioning effectively in a crosscultural environment. Our vocational school (bsnu) cannot transfer those skills completely as the curriculum only provides 45 minutes per week to train our students in English language and cross-cultural skills. According to academic studies native speakers of English can teach students, who learn English as a foreign language, more efficiently than  indigenous teachers. This course aims at improving our students’ professional competency as well as British culture and doing business in the United Kingdom. The course is designed for 24 participants. We will only take apprentices who attend our school and work in companies which provide business orientated training in professions like industrial clerks, logistics clerks or wholesale clerks. Sometimes we have applicants from the retail trade or students who are trained in managing warehouses. The majority of our students have an intermediate level of education. Only a small number of students have A-levels. Applying for our Erasmus+ project does not require A-levels. We recommend applying for participating in an Erasmus+ project of our school in the first or second year of their training because going to London in their final year may distract some students from preparing well for their final exams carried out by a chamber of commerce and industry. A group of bsnu teachers and Ms Sarah Iles of ECBM designed a concept and procedures for new Erasmus+ projects. We inform our students about new projects by handing out flyers and leaflets. We also put information about the projects on the bsnu website. Our teachers inform their students in the classrooms about our planned projects. We will send letters to companies which have taken apprentices to provide information about the project. When apprentices apply for participating in our project they must provide a written statement of their company showing they agree that their apprentice will be in London for three weeks during their regular period of vocational training. After evaluating the application forms we will choose the participants. If a company indicates their apprentices require English and cross-cultural skills on the job in an extensive manner, those applicants will be put on a priority list. The advices and recommendations of the remaining companies and of teachers from our school, who teach those applicants, will also be considered when choosing participants. In future we will not provide any English language courses for the participants. They have to use online courses provided by Erasmus+ to improve their English proficiency. However, we will go on providing cross-cultural training and a specific training for the ECBM course in London. We will only send one group of twentyfour students to London per year. According to our plans this will be in May/June 2018. Ms Yu Fengyan and Mr Albrecht Hofmann from our school will accompany the group when travelling to London. They will stay with the group in London for three weeks and will join the group on their journey back to Germany. The accompanying persons will monitor the group and their learning achievements. Ms Sarah Iles and the ECBM lecturers will be in charge of the teaching and motivation of the group while they are trained in London. After three weeks in London the participants can show in a presentation and in a written exam what they will have learned. After returning from London to Germany, the participants will have to write an executive summary in English (1000 words) about the topic which they presented as a PowerPoint presentation at ECBM. Our school will collect the participants’ documents and pass them on to ECBM in London. 
Unfortunately a majority of British people voted that Grat Britain should  leave the European Union (brexit). As we focused our international activities on the UK, we assume that in future there will be no EU-funded Erasmus+ projects with the UK as country of destination. We are searching new partners and networks in Ireland and Malta.
Auszubildende und Lehrer aus Bremen Erkunden Europa
European College of Business and Management

Our Internationalisation Concept is focussed on providing language and intercultural training for competent specialists with the option of obtaining further qualifications to enhance their mobility. At the heart of the development process towards achieving these declared aims lie the structuring and execution of additional international mobility projects.

Our three-week Business Communication Competence project in London has a number of core elements – acquiring intercultural competence through pertinent language seminars, the completion and presentation of a team project highlighting professional language fluency. It concludes with a certificate of proficiency graded according to the Common European Framework of Reference and will be offered in this form in future. In addition, it serves as a basis for the planning and execution of projects with an alternative concept: two-week placements in cooperation with tried and new partners with the objective of exchanging views and experience of professional practice through company visits and discussion with all of those involved in vocational training. Furthermore, relevant topics can be included flexibly, e.g. current developments in the EU.

Our contact to Lycée Pierre de Coubertin, Calais, will be reactivated. Rather than the previous three-week twinning with the emphasis on work placement, the future emphasis will be on small groups interacting and discussing. For trainees and teaching staff alike this should enable an international exchange of outlooks – not necessarily in English alone. Sitting in on lessons, company visits as well as extramural activities provide for enhanced intercultural competence and the opportunity for didactic reflection and development.

The relationship with Omnia, in Espoo, Finland, should develop along similar lines, whereby English will be paramount. By bringing together compatible professional sectors, greater emphasis will be placed on topics specifically related to the sector in question.

Our new partnership with LSE in Liverpool provides two further offers meeting our aspirations: for our apprentices language development is the primary objective flanked by company visits with groups formed more on the basis of the level of fluency rather than their training focus. As our English department expands and is strengthened through the Vocational College English Qualification at the Oldenburg Further Education Centre, Liverpool runs a particularly apposite intensive course culminating in the Cambridge Teaching Knowledge Test (TKT). Participants not only consolidate specific vocabulary, but also through teaching their main subject to the Liverpool study group explore, expand and develop didactic approaches. A parallel course offered by the established International Study Programme gives us even greater flexibility to enable our staff to acquire further qualifications.

Hitherto we have offered our apprentices the professional KMK English Language certificate at Level B2. The successful initiation of the Europakaufmann qualification in cooperation with five other internationally engaged Bremen vocational colleges has attracted 47 participants in 2017. Along with concentration on the theme of International Commerce, the English KMK Certificate Level B1, qualification in a further foreign language at minimum Level A1 and the ECDL, a three-week work placement abroad with intercultural interaction is also required. For this we have the partners Liverpool and ECBM with their great experience. The europass will be issued for this.

Sending staff to support participants has definitely enhanced the success and quality of our Mobility projects to date and further strengthened the Internationalisation awareness of accompanying staff. Our expanding concept for Mobility involves intensifying the participation of staff in project activities. They will have the added opportunity for comparing international approaches to vocational training and an exchange on didactics with their opposite numbers in vocational institutions. The ensuing reflection and multiplication of their experiences in various locations will promote the internationalisation of our college.

Based on the contents of the Internationalization Strategic Plan (version 2015) the same aims the strengthening and consolidation of services currently in place and the strengthening of the networks of which Accademia europea di Firenze is already a member.
In particular according with the Plan, it will proceed, for 2017-2019, to:
-manage Europedirect Service under Municipality of Florence, to support educational quality processes of European programs and in particular on international mobility, as a learning tool and qualification
-improved, making system and dissemination of their own management tools and mentoring of international mobility paths, through continuous update of the manual about management of mobility path and born through the T-Tactic @ School project (www.tactic@school.eu)
- consolidation of local networks and international partnership; Stronger and powerful  of vocational courses on the subject of europrojecting, specifically aimed at teachers of secondary school (thanks to the accreditation of the courses at the Ministry of Education) of the region covered by the training and with the right to exemption; upgrading training for counselors and personal shopper; for all paths it provides for the possibility to carry out the training as a part  of international apprenticeship
-implementation and use of the online platform created under the EU project  JOBS IMPULSE (www.gojobgo.eu), funded by the Erasmus + KA2 action program for job seekers and for people who  gained experience of international mobility in order to facilitate the entrance into the job market . Other aims is, also, to make visible and accessible the European instruments for the recognition, validation and the transparency of skills and qualifications
The planned activities within the project S.A.T  allow to implement the actions mentioned above in the following way:
1)International  Internship for  5 students of AEF attending courses on Europrojecting, , counseling and personal shopper. This activity will be held for 10 days (+ 2 travel) in the UK and Spain
The LO identified are:
Counselor: Knowledge of the national legislation and the qualifications system (professional counselor); ability to work in team and create synergies with other personal care services; uses knowledge of counseling techniques and support to educational paths or growth; ability to work in a European language in mother tongue; empathic attitude and respect for diversity.
Europrojecting: understanding of the European framework; knowledge Erasmus + program and its various actions with specific depending on the hosting companies focus; understanding call for proposals; skills in identifying needs and defining objectives of a project; ability to work in teams; ability to work in a European language in mother tongue; ability to process design and synthesis report; autonomy and respect for diversity.
Personal shopper: ability to identify the needs and tastes of the customer; ability to identify, with the customer, the main shopping areas and the target market segments; knowledge of photoshop and adobe; marketing knowledge, strategic communication; ability to work in a European language other than their mother tongue, in a multicultural team, ability to establish empathetic relationships with customers, respect for diversity.
2) International Internship for 5 graduates, 2 of which with attendant basic care qualification and 3 with beautician qualification. This activity will be held for 30 days (+ 2 travel) in Spain and Malta
The LO identified are:
(ADB) to support the user's autonomy, addressing situations of need, implement therapeutic programs, implement simple sanitation interventions;
(Beautician) apply construction techniques, sanitation, operating environments for beauty treatments
3) International Internship for 5 tutors. This activity will be held for 10 days (+ 2 travel) in the UK and Spain.
The LO identified for tutors are: consolidation of basic knowledge in support of the coaching theories; knowledge principles of mentoring; knowledge of tutoring tools in different locations depending on the receiving facilities; ability to establish empathetic relationships; active listening skills, openness attitude; genuine respect for diversity; tolerance of ambiguity. 
The 3 activities include management as stated in VET Charter. Accompany persons are not provide as it's an adult audience and self. The project will be realized in the following flows: 5 people in June 2018, 5 people in February 2019, 5 people in March2019.

These tasks were foreseen for development of internalisation:
1.To iniciate and implement international projects, to encourage interaction between school and companies, to create conditions for teachers and students to adopt technological inovations, foster entrepreneurship, multiculturalism. 
2.To create conditions for teachers and students to participate in exhange programmes and skill competitions.
3.To be a host organisation in Erasmus+ projects, to organise  exhange programmes for incoming teachers and students, to share the best experience.
4.To cooperate with business companies, to participate in projects together. To invite professionals-lecturers from abroad.
5.To intensify cooperation with partners from North and South Europe, United Kingdom.
6.To strenghten mentoring, assurance of the quality in projects.
Plan is to send 40 students and 24  teachers for placements. One incoming teaching visits is planned (from Italy).
Partnerships with Belgium,  Portugal, France are updated, closer cooperation with vocational schools. ECVET elements are negotiated  with the host partners, in order to reach better students‘ achievements recognition.
It is planned to send various specialties students, according to internalisation strategy. Cooks, waiters and bartenders, confectioners, recreational service workers,  sport club activities organizers will go to placements. They  will go to Spain (2 flows 7 students in one flow), 10 students to United Kingdom, 10 cooks to Italy, 6 students to Portugal. It is planned to send leading teachers to all countries.
Teachers will go to a job shadowing visits to Belgium, Spain, United Kingdom and France. Participants will visit vocational schools with similar teaching programmes and basis. Topic of the visits: assurance of vocational training quality. They will observe colleagues‘ work, discuss practical training organisation issues, evaluation and self-evaluation documents, help and mentoring of pupils. Vocational teachers and administration will go to visits, they  learn about educational systems, quality management, plan further students‘ placements. Teachers‘ visits will be recognised as improvement of   qualification, they will be asked to describe the impact and present new experience to colleagues, students.

Marks and results will be transfered to a student diary, as part of practical training abroad, it will be recognised, according to agreed topics with vocational teacher, host organisation, and a participant  in advance. Project coordinator, vocational teachers and mentor will cooperate.

School improves status in region, is becoming more open and atractive  to society, social partners, promotes vocational training.

Project dissemination  activities. Participants will prepare reports, present gained experience, knowledge to teachers, trainers and community. The final meeting will be organized after implementation of the project, representatives of  vocational  schools, social partners will be invited. The project called "Modern and effective ways of teaching" is submitted by the teachers of Hotel Academy in Kežmarok, the school with a long tradition in the region with great potential for the development of tourism in the Slovak Republic. They focus their attention on improvement of language learning as well as Economics and Geography and subsequently a better position of graduates in the European labour market.

The main objectives of the project are improvement of language competences, introduction of innovative methods, making teaching profession more attractive, reinforcing the profile of executive branch of school management, experience and comparison of advanced educational systems in Europe and networking between schools.

The project involves nine participants, the teachers with ambitions of self-realization and further professional growth who have chosen the partner institutions in countries with a developed educational system - Northern Europe (Denmark, Iceland), the United Kingdom, Latvia, Spain and Greece. The participants will complete the educational activities according to the schedule and with the help of a contact person they will inform each other and report their progress. Following the completion of all activities and the entire project, they will implement their new knowledge into their lessons. The results of the project activities will also be published on school website or in the local media. Long-term benefits of the project should be establishing international contacts for the subsequent KA2 project for the students of our school.

"Cultivating Europe" originates from the Institute’s need for more internationalization in response to the geographical marginality and distance from large urban centers, which causes a strong isolation of the population, especially the school that is characterized by limited relationships and stimulations. The Omni-Inclusive Institute located in Marsicovetere, which acts such as a  gravitational center of civic, cultural, creative exchanges, needs greater openness towards its own territory, to the country and Europe in general.
The Institute’s need to promote and encourage cooperation in all of its forms as essential element in the development of its educational system, was made evident in the POF and it was drawn up after a detailed analysis of students’ training needs, and it is considered necessary especially in response to the European development plan, outlined by the project staff. Concrete data show very high percentages of low academic performance in scientific and technical subjects (70% of pupils in primary and secondary schools and 35 % of students of the ITA, with a peak of 43% in the fourth grade) and the need to take action, starting from kindergarten, through adequate responses to special educational needs for the prevention of possible criticisms (in nursery school, 6.8% of children show already special educational needs).
Therefore, considering these training needs and in order to acquire new teaching models for a more cooperative and practical didactics, further it is able to involve students, enhancing their resources and paying attention to their needs, the project involves 25 teachers for job shadowing activities and structured courses in the UK, France and Malta for a period of 17 days, including 2 days of travel. In particular, the outlined plan of organization expects  the improvement of teachers’ knowledges, skills and abilities through targeted training activities that share the goal of re-structuring the educational curriculum and the consequent strengthening of  teaching.
In fact, the project intends, at the end of the experience, to proceed towards the formulation of a new vertical curriculum, applicable to all types and levels, born out of the internationalization experience and able to offer students the opportunity to improve their academic performance, combining knowledge and action. Therefore, the project staff, after an operative meeting, has defined the following objectives: developing a new vertical curriculum applicable to all types and levels of education; integrating CLIL methodology within daily training plan; implementing innovative training methods for DL: tasked based learning and cooperative learning; improving the knowledge of a foreign language; enhancing the digital skills of teachers in order to integrate new technologies in education and creating opportunities for debates and collaborations; adequately responding to special demands of attention; enhancing teaching skills for more innovative teaching and learning processes so as to meet the national established guidelines; transferring to students the knowledge acquired abroad; increasing the awareness and use of learning materials regarding the issues of environmental education and, in particular, of the agri-food and wine industry.
As a result of this project, 4 workshop activities will be activated: 1 Lab for children of kindergarten, two workshops focusing on issues such as viticulture and intended for pupils of primary and secondary levels and second degree and 1 language laboratory, aimed at creating a direct contact between the students of the sending institute and the pupils from the partner institutions. 2 didactic units will also be integrated in curricular lessons and they will be in CLIL mode (tasked based learning and cooperative learning methodologies). After the mobility and the activities that will be implemented within the Institute, it is expected, in terms of impact and in response to the European development plan, that teachers will be able, with the help of new methods, to improve the academic performance of pupils at least of 50% and to affect positively on 80% of the special attention requests coming from the nursery school. It is also expected a wider openness to the territory,  the country and Europe in general.
SP w Markowej - rozwój kadry podstawą rozwoju szkoły i uczniów

'SP in Markowa - Development of Staff as the Basis for the Development of School and Students' is a project prepared by the Primary School in Markowa (Powiat Łańcucki, Podkarpackie Voivodeship). During the twelve months, starting from September 1, 2018, participants will acquire knowledge and skills allowing the implementation of new solutions and methods aimed at activating students, integrating disabled children with peers, improving communication with parents. The project involves pedagogical-cultural-linguistic preparation in order to adapt the participants to mobility.

Activities will have two dimensions: the first is the improvement of the methodological workshop and intercultural and language education during three training trips to Malta (15 teachers) and to England (5 teachers); the second is the transfer of acquired competences to school teachers (another 19 educators).

The most important goals of the project are:
1. Strengthening the potential of the Szkoła Podstawowa im. Sług Bożych Rodziny Ulmów w Markowej  by undertaking international cooperation with partners from Great Britain and Malta and participation of 20 representatives of the staff in methodological and language courses during the project implementation period, ie 01/09/2018 - 31/08/2019.
2. Increasing the English language competence of five English advanced teachers in order to improve the English student learning process
3. Increasing language competences in English 15 teachers in order to include elements of a foreign language in the school programme;
4. Increase of competences of 20 teachers participating in the project depending on selected courses in the scope of:
 - building students' creativity and solving problems and creating appropriate conditions for the development and promotion of critical thinking among children and the teaching community (Creative & Critical Mind course)
- Verification and development of pedagogical and communication skills, improvement of prospects and development opportunities of each student through communication with parents (Parents & Teachers course)
- Effective support of the student development process, improvement of communication skills and the process of building relationships between a disabled student and classmates (All Children Are Special course)

The partners of the school are experienced training organizers in Malta (Paragon Europe) and in England (Language Link London ltd), who will be responsible for the implementation and evaluation of the project collectively  with a competent Polish project team. The course of the project will be regularly monitored and evaluated. Monitoring will take place in three stages (before the start, after 6 months and at the end of the project). It will be conducted using the interview method with participants and the method of survey questionnaire (language-cultural test and questionnaire).

The results and products of the project will be regularly published on the project and partner websites. It is planned to issue a bulletin with lessons plans and descriptions of conducting classes in schools with methods practiced as part of this project. The materials produced will be published on the e-Twinning and School Education Gateway as part of the Open Educational Resources. Participants of the project will receive participation certificates, Europass Mobility, and in the Europass CV which will be used for the  recruitment process.

The implemented project is an element of improving the quality of didactic work at the school in Markowa included in the new Work Program of the School and the European Development Plan, in order to increase the key competences of local teachers and students, promote the school's brand and integrate the local environment with the school.
Internationaler Kaufmann - Neue Wege in der Berufsausbildung für Industriekaufleute
European College of Business and Management

We see our newly prepared course „Internationaler Kaufmann – Neue Wege in der Berufsbildung für Industriekaufleute” as integrated foreign-language training. In advance the students are trained in a plus-programme at our vocational school in terms of data processing, foreign language, sociopolitical topics and giving presentations. In a three-week course at the European College of Business and Management in London, with 26 teaching units a week, the pupils apply their knowledge by giving short talks, preparing power point presentations and writing compositions about economic and politico-economic tasks in English. In addition they have typical Business English units such as correspondence, telephoning and cultural differences. The cross-cultural competence will be improved by several excursions. The written project report (approximately 1500 words) will be completed and edited (text processing, image editing, graphics) after the stay at home. These reports will be passed on to the European College to be assessed. 
The students can acquire three certificates: German-British Chamber Certificate, European College of Business and Management Attendance Certificate and the Europass.
To acquire these certificates the students need to perform the following efforts:
Written project report (approximately 1500 words) after the end of the course at home, a power point presentation about an economic topic, a three hour written test.
We are planning to integrate the results of the mobility in the report marks and the comment of the school certificate of 11th grade. In this connection we want to check to which extent the separate achievements of the mobility can be transferred into report marks. This is what we want to develop in close cooperation with our school management, the Government of Swabia and the Ministry of Education.
Absolutely essential for us is the improvement of the monitoring.
We are planning:
- All steps of preparation being evaluated by the students
- Students take notes of their progress in a project diary
- The host families being evaluated by the students
- The content of the courses and the teachers of the ECBM being assessed
- The professionalism of the project management of the teachers of our school being validated.
In addition we want the whole project to be evaluated by the trainers of the participating KMUs.
As result of the consistent further development of our project series the pupils receive the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” in cooperation with the DIHK Berlin.
The requirements for this certificate, which was developed by the AHK in London, are:
1. Successful conclusion of the apprenticeship to become an industrial clerk
2. Successful completion of the three week mobility in London (PDP-Programme at the ECBM in London (written and oral exam plus essay))
Additionally we demand at least good results in the KMK-Certificate in Business English level 2.
If all qualifications are fulfilled the certification “Internationaler Kaufmann” will be carried out by the ECBM in London.
Erwerb der Zusatzqualifikation "Internationaler Kaufmann AHK" in London für kaufmännische Auszubildende sowie interkulturelle und sprachliche Fortbildung von Lehrkräften im englischsprachigen Ausland
European College of Business and Management

The vocational school no. 2 in Traunstein sharpens its international reputation. This is done by establishing a course to qualify its pupils for international trade as addition to the existing school partnerships. Also teachers are given the opportunity to get an insight view into the changes in the economical sector of Britain and its neighbours caused by the Brexit. All participants will also increase their language skills.

Mobility of apprentices:

The vocational school no. 2 in Traunstein offers a further internationally accepted certificate to interested apprentices in the field of business management. This is the "Internationale Kaufmann AHK London" in cooperation with the "European College of Business and Management" in London. The ECBM is the officially accredited college of the German-British Chamber of Industry & Commerce (AHK) in London.
 
During this course the participants can acquire knowledge and skills on a higher level than they would during their normal apprenticeship. This will result in a better understanding of international trade and behaviour.

This Certificate can be obtained by attending and passing a 3-weekly course in London and by successfully passing the final examination of the "Industrie- und Handelskammer" or "Handwerkskammer" examination in Germany.

Obtaining this cerficate adds substantially to the professional background of the participants and will increase career opportunities and promotion to higher levels.

The employers encourage this programme actively by releasing their trainees from work for the duration of the course as they see the additional skills their trainees can obtain and contribute to their workplace. 

During their stay in London they will lodge with host families and commute to the ECBM. Here they will experience the real life in the English capital which is determined by permanent changes, a for Germans unfamiliar service orientation, awareness of tradition, politeness to name only a few. These experiences will have a long lasting effect on how they view other cultures.  In addition to that the international surrounding, which they will face in this multicultural city, will expand their experience and their horizon.

Excursions at the weekends will, show them the other England, the quiet and relaxed life in rural areas. All this should give them a good overview of the English society. 

The influence on the participants´ language skills will be considerable and will reduce the fear of using the language both orally or in writing.

Teacher mobility:

Teachers will improve their language skills and their understanding of international trade especially in the sector of further education institutions in England. In addition they will improve their intercultural understanding and their project management skills. They can take part in lectures which are unrelated to their own subjects in Germany, so they can enhance their knowledge and teaching skills. 
In addition their intercultural competences will increase, by questioning their value system and eventually adjusting it. 
They will experience the impacts of Brexit in England on the media, the society and politics .
Kaufmännische Auszubildende in England und Estland
European College of Business and Management

The Kaufmännische Schulen 1 Villingen-Schwenningen (KS1), Kaufmännische Schulen Göppingen (KSGÖ) and Kaufmännische Schulen Offenburg (KSOG) would like to enable young apprentices to get work experience abroad as part of their dual training (e.g. as industrial clerks or financial assistants). The aim of this is an increased intercultural and personal competence to help master new challenges in business as well as personal life. Businesses, which are very often internationally orientated, would thus benefit from highly motivated employees who would be more self-assured in their treatment of foreign customers and suppliers. Participation in the project can also lead to enhanced willingness to work abroad inside the EU.
The project is aimed at students with university entry qualification and those entitled to study at specialist colleges and universities of applied sciences, whose level of proficiency in English is at least B2 (for Great Britain), and good students who graduated from middle school with a sound knowledge of English, which they can use to bridge communication gaps (for Estonia). The participants will be apprentices of various different professions in their second year of training. The focus will be on bank clerks, industrial clerks as well as clerks in administration, but the project will be open to all other professions, like office clerks and automotive clerks. At the time of departure, students in three-year courses will have passed about one half of their training, those in two-year courses (e.g. financial assistants) will have passed about two-thirds of their training. This will guarantee that they have sufficient qualification, competence and profound basic knowledge of economics to benefit from the internships and other offers that are part of the project.

In Great Britain, the focus of the project is on obtaining the “office worker international – AHK” qualification of the German-British Chamber of Commerce.
In Estonia, the project focuses on “seeing beyond the end of one’s nose”.
In both countries, participants are supposed to strengthen their key qualifications – teamwork, problem solving, testing self-organised procedures. In Estonia, special emphasis will be on doing an internship, forming ties in the twinning schools and finding one’s way on new terrain.
In the course of two years, 80 apprentices are to be sent to Great Britain, and 12 to Estonia.
All partners in the project have been in contact for a number of years, and procedures and coordination before and during the stays are will-known, tried and tested. Dates for the stays have already been appointed, same as the coordination of course contents. In Great Britain, the ECBM course includes English Business Communication, excursions to the Docklands and an oral exam as well as a written essay exam. In Estonia, the agenda includes participating in classes at the two business colleges, a one-week internship, a visit to the German Embassy as well as guided tours of Tallinn, Riga and Helsinki, which will be prepared by the participants themselves.

To sum up, the project is meant to render the participating students highly independent in planning and organising their own learning situations and environment. It is a long-term goal to enhance mobility and to prepare the students for an unknown environment, as it is less and less likely for them to remain in the places where they are being trained. Intercultural competence is becoming increasingly important at school and in the workplace, with colleagues just as with customers. When dealing with them, it is of particular importance to show understanding and empathy, especially for those who come from foreign nations and cultures. Self-organisation of exchange processes is of central pedagogical importance in this project. The participants will have to let themselves in for each other, make decisions together and coordinate their decisions with those of others. Self-organisation is a crucial educational aim which is meant to enable the young people to be resourceful and to take the initiative. This will further creativity and facilitate professional development. Taking the initiative and accepting responsibility for one’s decisions are basic prerequisites for successful professional progress.
Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational education VI

In our project are trainees of several programmes included. There are trainees, who are educated full time in school, we call them "Assistenten", the name of this kind of education programme is Höhere Berufsfachschule (HBFS), within this programme we have four emphases, these are Chemical technology (Chemical technicians), Biological technology (Biological technicians), Media design and information technology.
Additionally to the full time in school educated trainees we include trainees (mostly Biological Lab Assistants) out of the so called dual system.
The main topic of the project "Come together in Europe; technical and cultural exchange as part of vocational training VI" is to provide opportunities to our trainees, who come almost out of the rural surroundings of our school, to make vocational experiences abroad in Europe.
We think that the young generation of the current trainees at the time of globalisation won't be able to stay for their whole professional life at home near their place of birth or their place of youth. They will have to be ready to join companies abroad, if they want to be successful in their jobs. In Sweden, as well as in the other countries where we are looking for options for internships, the trainees will meet foreign working cultures, which will not be common to them. They will learn to be a stranger the hard way, during their four week placements. We think this will help to develop broad-mindedness and acceptance for foreign people and cultures within their companies and living environment at home in the rural area of Marburg. Hopefully they will educate their fellow pupils in this way, when they are back from the four week internships.
The coaching of the students abroad will force us teachers as well. Our foreign language competences, especially our skills in using the technical language will increase by the communication with the instructors in the companies abroad. This will have positive effects not only to us but also to the pupils, who were not brave enough so far to do an internship abroad.
Die Zukunft des Finanzstandorts London nach dem Brexit
European College of Business and Management

Since 1999 we have been conducting the project in London in cooperation with the „“European College of Business and Management” (ECBM). We have established the project for the apprentices of Investment Fund Administration and we have been extending it to the benefit of our apprentices in Banking. We are currently sending 40 students to London.

The new title of the project “TThe future of London’s financial center after the Brexit" clearly describes our aim that future bank employees should challenge and better understand UK’s relationship with Europe. They should discuss the consequences of Britain remaining member of the EU or Britain leaving  the EU.  Furthermore, they should be able to act responsibly and confidently at international financial places. During their stay in London the students are supposed to discover the banking centre London with its severe problems as well as learn about British economy and politics.  Visiting the docklands, the Bank of England and the Stock Exchange, for example, our students will get a deeper insight into London.

The target group of our project are apprentices of Investment Fund Administration and apprentices in Banking who started their traineeship one year ago. They have already passed their intermediate examination and have received theoretical training in form of block teaching in our vocational school. Their employers are mainly banks and investment fund companies in Frankfurt.

In London students mainly spend their time in college and get to know the city as a financial centre. The college works out a training scheme tailored to needs of our students and is responsible for teaching the subjects. The lessons are held by native speakers. Excursions are also a part of the training programme. At the end of the stay the students have to pass several exams to receive three certificates:
- Certificate of the ECBM 
- Certificate of the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce
- Kaufmann/Kauffrau International (AHK)
- Certification of participation in the OLS language course.

Early planning is very important for us: in September 2016 the college, the flights and the hotel rooms have to be reserved. When booking the flight we also apply for a travel cancellation insurance which covers the students’ own contribution of 650 euros. For many years now we have been guests at the Lancaster Hall Hotel in London and we have been working with the college and our travel agency. 

It’s our aim that students improve their professional, social, intercultural and linguistic skills. The following vocational and social competences should be expanded: the participants should discover the banking centre London and they should follow the college lessons about economic, political and cultural topics held in English. Furthermore they have to live and work with students of other institutions in an unknown surrounding. This requires a high level of social responsibility. The participants will get to know a foreign culture, because London itself is a melting pot of cultures. Going to the college by tube or going to museums are also part of the students’ intercultural experiences in a very open and tolerant society. In discussions with their professors they will automatically think about the different strategies that the two countries have to solve their problems. Since the dominant language in the financial sector is English  the students will gain professional as well as linguistic profit.
European College of Business and Management

Marketing in the Real Estate Industry

This mobility measure is directed at German apprentices in Berlin receiving dual vocational education and training as a qualified real estate management assistant. Twenty-five participants will attend the seminar called  "Marketing in the Real Estate Industry"  at the European College of Business and Management in London in autumn 2018. The students will stay with host families in London.

During the first half of their three-week visit, all apprentices receive lessons focussing on the housing market of Great Britain in order to carry out their projects as well as to gain a wider understanding of marketing. Teachers also refer to the latest developments of Britain’s, particularly London’s, housing market. Participants form groups of two or three to work on a certain topic, which they have chosen before. During that time students work independently most of the time, the college offers assistance if necessary, e.g. providing literature, computer workstations and teachers’ support. To fulfill the project’s requirements, students need to carry out interviews in companies, for example. At the end they will get a mark for their project which consists of a Powerpoint presentation and a ten-page executive summary. The executive summary of their project is to be handed in after their mobility. Furthermore, they write a three-hour exam in the last week.

The seminar is activity-oriented and will primarily focus on key competences such as the ability to work in a team, independent learning as well as verbal and non-verbal communication skills. Students mainly acquire proficiency in the English language and in dealing with foreign cultures. Besides, their experience abroad and the certificates awarded enhance their labour market position.

After successfully completing the project, participants will receive the following certificates:
- Certificate of the European College of Business and Management)
- Kaufmann International Certificate of the German-British Chamber of Commerce
- Europass Mobility
European College of Business and Management

Context/Background:
The business sector that drives Germany’s economy is the export sector.  The Fachakademie in Nuremberg has been founded to provide this sector with skilled employees. The state certified business managers that graduate at the FAW have excellent  communication skills regarding language and intercultural understanding, which they acquire by participating in the above mentioned project. Most of the participants in the project will enhance their careers by working abroad inside Europe as well as overseas. 

Target group: 
20 participants  who have successfully completed an apprenticeship in the business sector and are currently in further education as state-certified business managers
Duration: 3 weeks 

Objectives:
After graduating the participants mainly pick jobs in an international environment (in Europe and outside Europe), so they have a strong interest in foreign cultures and a willingness to accept  cultural differences and adhere to them.  So the main aims are 
- to  mprove language skills and intercultural competence and 
- to increase self-confidence in liaising with foreign business partners (clients and suppliers).
Both  lead to  better employment opportunities.


Activities:
- Business Communications/ Negotiating Skills, Telephoning, Communication at Work, Leadership and Management: --> gaining more self-confidence in dealing with business partners by actively using training methods
- Business Communications/ Writing CVs and Letters of Application, Interview Techniques /Social Media: -->gaining knowledge about international requirements regarding applications, importance of networking 
- Business Case Studies/ Differences / Corporate Culture --> introduction into operating processes in other countries
Britain in the EU/British Politics/Law/ Marketing/Media. --> increasing intercultural awareness and tolerance 
Tasks:
Written exam
PowerPoint Presentation about a business topic
Executive summary  

Validation:
- ECBM Certificate of Attendance 
- German-British Chamber Certificate  
- Kaufmann/Kauffrau International Qualification  
- Europass

Methodology:
The contents has been developed over the years from experience of the partners and from feedback of the participants. Every year the time table is reviewed and partly altered according to current requirements and also current global developments (e.g. financial crisis)

Preparation and evaluation:
There are e fivsessions, in which the participants are informed and learn about the following topics:
1. Contract agreements etc. Erasmus+
2. Preparation Pack of ECBM, validity of certificates, travel arrangements etc.,
3. Preparation of project work, project choice, London as cultural location  / Presentation techniques, layout  and structure of executive summary,
4.  Final organisation (emergency contact details) outlook , dates and deadlines (feedback etc.), current affairs
5. Evaluation (Feedback, questionnaires, discussions etc.)


Results/Outcomes:
- better employment chances on the international market (increasingly important)
- valid certificates increase competitiveness of participants on the labour market
- higher recognition by big companies/ global players who are located in the area
- increased motivation to achieve higher qualification and degrees (Bachelor and Master degrees). Increasingly important as transparency and comparability of degrees has been entered into a European framework .
- higher flexibility and mobility
- better negotiating skills in dealing with international business partners
- improved organizational and IT skills 
- high competence in English as the globalised world’s business language 

The results of  the past years  show increased self-confidence  regarding personal as well as business skills. Increasingly participants apply for jobs abroad and also take up further qualification opportunities that are offered by the ECBM.  All this qualifies them further on the European market and enhances their general understanding of the necessity to think globally. The success of the German economy and the people who are employed depends on Europe.  The power lies in the community. However this requires a strong determination, tolerance and also the necessary competence. The project  contributes essentially to strengthening those skills.
European College of Business and Management

General overview:

The staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen (state-owned vocational school) is planning to send a total forty German students as well as up to ten German teachers from its economics department to London for three weeks. These stays are scheduled for April 2019 and April 2020. During that time, they will be working at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM). The ECBM is the training college of the German-British Chamber of Commerce. It was founded in 1988 and is well established in the fields of basic and continuous training. They offer the "Professional Development Programme" (PDP), a 3-week intensive course, which is tailored to our students' needs. During the PDP, our students will complete and earn the certificate of “Kaufmann International (KIC)”. This certificate is awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London). This is supposed to ensure that the qualifications and skills gained abroad will improve the students' chances in the job market and that the experiences abroad will have a lasting effect. 

Selection process:

The selection process for the project will be taking place in two different ways. Students from the economics department taking part in the additional qualification "foreign language correspondence clerk" offered by the Chamber of Industry and Commerce (IHK), will be part of the project as well as other applicants from the economics department. All participating students are obliged to hand in a letter of motivation as well as the Europass CV.
The participating teachers in the project are chosen on the basis of their willingness to take part in the project. In the long term, the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen is planning to extend the number of people involved in the project as it is one of the main objectives of the school to deepen its internationalisation strategy.

Main objectives of the project, concerning students and teachers:

Enhancing professional skills and competences:

One key objective of the project is a further qualification of the trainees of our economics department. Many of them are doing their traineeship in internationally operating companies. Therefore, they should gain job-related experience abroad as soon as possible. Getting insights into international business processes and using English as the language of business are elements that give these students a professional and personal advantage. Therefore, we are helping our students to be successful on the European labour market. 
Our teachers, taking part in the project gain insights in planning and conducting European projects and exchange skills and methods with English-speaking colleagues.

Developing personal skills and competences:

Besides, spending time abroad is helping the students to overcome fears of foreign things and helps them to gain intercultural competences. Our students live in small villages in rural Upper Bavaria. Spending three weeks in multicultural London will make a huge impression on them. Besides, working and living abroad in host families will contribute to a positive personal development. That will also help to promote tolerance and to eliminate prejudices.
Our teachers also profit from staying abroad and strengthen their insights into the European idea. Intercultural competences can only be communicated if one is convinced of the idea oneself.

Objectives of the project, concerning the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen and its partners:

The staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen wants to extend its internationalisation strategy. We want to create a network of national and international partners, from which everyone (companies, students, teacher, and our foreign partners) can profit. Even though, the staatliche Berufsschule Pfaffenhofen is located in the economically very prosperous region north of Munich, which is constantly profiting from a steady influx of people, demographic change has got an impact on all institutions in vocational training. As a consequence, we see internationalisation as a chance to improve our chances as well as those of our partners in the economy to get highly motivated, productive and cosmopolitan trainees.
European College of Business and Management

Introduction:
The topics of language learning and multilingualism play an important part in the economy. Europe is characterised by its linguistc and cultural diversity. As a continent where three dozen languages are spoken, it is known for the high number of cultures that border on one another. But Europe means more than being able to travel and work without frontiers and customs: Europe is a true vision of society and understanding.

Within the framework of globalisation, there is a greater demand than ever for multilingualism. Hardly any company can survive without international links. There is a growing need for international staff who speak foreign languages. As citizens of Europe we must be able to communicate and co-operate across borders and cultures...

Background and Participants:
Students completing a vocational education as Commercial Assistants at the Kolping College of Commerce and Foreign Languages in Heilbronn enjoy a predominantly theoretical education. In order to enhance the quality of their training and to improve the employment prospects of our young students, it is desirable for their education to include a period of practical experience abroad. Within the framework of this project, a total of approximately 25 future commercial assistants from both the first and second years of the course will take part in three-week study trips to Spain or Great Britain during the spring of 2019. At this juncture, they have yet to gain any practical experience in a foreign country.

Activities:
The activities comprise instruction in the foreign language and business administration at partner institutes, company visits, excursions and school projects, as well as cultural events. Participants orient themselves by the GUIDE they themselves have created and, in addition, complete their project "A DIFFERENT DAILY ROUTINE". The contents of the trip are organised so as to complement and augment the mostly theoretical education provided by the College.

Aims of the Project:
The study trips are founded on the three elements of the foreign language and culture, and the world of business, and are designed to achieve goals relevant to the students' education. The knowledge students have acquired of the foreign language in the classroom can be tried out and deepened in another European country. Students are given the opportunity to undertake operational tasks while gaining an insight into the business life of the foreign country and familiarising themselves with its work culture and lifestyle. The encounter with the country's culture takes the form of their daily routine combined with visits to museums and the theatre.

Procedure and Implementation:
We remain in continuous contact with our partner institutes, so that we can involve students, parents, teachers and the college as a whole during the course of the year leading up to a study trip. As soon as assurance of support has been granted, the project managers contact our partner institutes in order to co-ordinate the details. Host families are selected by our partner institutes. The project management team deals with the organisation of the trip and the formalities of insurance and legal contracts, also communicating with the parents of the participants on these matters. The students themselves finally draw up the supporting programme as well as their GUIDE as part of their course in project management at the College.
Aims and Benefits:
Participants write reports in which they present their results and how they personally have benefited from the study trip. 

The results we aspire to achieve are to increase participants' abilities in the foreign language as well as their intercultural competence, and to improve their school marks and education. In addition, they gain practical experience, a more attractive profile for their CV, and contacts at companies in other European countries, all of which are beneficial when seeking future employment. There are long-term gains not only for the future careers of our participants but also for firms, inasmuch as they are provided with well-educated skilled personnel.

One result our institute strives for is to foster close and trusting ties  to our co-operation partners in other European countries and the willingness to conduct further mobility and other EU projects.

A final positive effect is the promotion of the European vision through the international orientation of our vocational training. 

These study trips may be interpreted as part of a great story helping us to understand others, the people we live together with as Europeans.
The Real Estate Sector in London and the UK
European College of Business and Management

The Professional Development Programme "The Real Estate Sector in London and the UK" provides a 3-week intensive course for 24 apprentices of the housing industry, who are currently being schooled at the vocational school Berufskolleg des Europäischen Bildungszentrums der Wohnungs- und Immobilienwirtschaft (EBZ Bochum). The PDP is offered by the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London, where students receive the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate awarded by the EHK London.

For ten years now, our apprentices take part in the Professional Development Programmes at the ECBM London. This course provides the young learners with specific knowledge in business administration, interculturality and language. The focus on the real estate industry has been thoroughly developed in cooperation between both institutes, and has  grown into a very successful means to support young professionals in their employability as well as their companies' international development.

To have a look into markets and market actors of the real estate sector in the UK and London in detail, supports the learners' professional approach and supports the further enhancement of the skills and abilities demanded by changing market environments.

All participants are currently in their dual vocational training at the EBZ and their sending companies, and thus profit from this tailor-made course which enhances their independence and flexibility as future actors in real estate. 

Furthermore, the programme supports the further internationalisation of the vocational training branch of the EBZ-Group.
European College of Business and Management

In a united Europe aspects such as experiences across the continent and the knowledge of foreign languages become more and more important and evident. The Louis-Baare-Berufskolleg is a vocational college where students complete their training or obtain other educational qualifications. As a so-called "Europaschule" we account for this development.

While doing their work placements and studies as part of the project the selected students gain the above mentioned competences.  These competences cover the needs of the German economy on a global market. The selected participants provide their linguistic and technical skills to the internship company. The successful achievement of everyday work in a company as well as the process of gaining knowledge abroad strenghtens their self confidence. Moreover they learn more about different working methods and mentalities. Through this the students enhance their career prospects within the European Union. Furthermore making positive experiences beyond national borders and also making new friends in other countries reduces prejudices, stereotypes and fears.

Overall 44 students will participate in the programme. Before their stay abroad all students will be prepared for their placements and studies. This includes practical support concerning the organization locally (the booking of flights, accommodation etc.). They will either be accompanied by a teacher or supported via e-mail or telephone. In addition it is planned to visit as many of them as possible.
Der Lebensstandard einer Familie im europäischen Vergleich

The vocational training at the dual vocational college (Duales Berufskolleg) incorporates a job placement of several weeks or months. The trainees in the Ortenaukreis, as well as the training companies, the zweiteSchule gemeinnützige Gesellschaft (a non-profit organization), and the Kaufmännische Schulen Lahr work closely together for the mobility project. Local companies have been sending their trainees to European subsidiaries and other cooperating companies for several years as a mobility activity. It is indispensible for local companies depending on export to encourage their trainees’ language skills. The results of the mobility activities over the last years have shown that the participants not only improved their language skills but furthermore enriched their intercultural and methodological competences, not to speak of their positive personal development and tolerance. The "European thought" can be considered as a long-term benefit. The involved companies and the Kaufmännische Schulen Lahr are committed to an improvement of these competencies. 
The mobility project is going to take place from July until the end of september 2018.  Twenty of 28 trainees of the class in the "Duales Berufskolleg" are going to do their job placements in the UK, France,  Italy, Poland and  Norway. The trainees of the Duales Berufskolleg are required to complete a job placement for several weeks or months during their training. The training companies completely support this measure since they profit from the knowledge and the skills that the trainees acquire in the partner companies abroad. An important part of the mobility measure is the realization of a project which usually deals with current European topics. It is supposed to improve first and foremost the trainees’ linguistic and social skills. 
The chosen topic should investigate and reveal  the standard of living in connection with  labour and education policy of our European neighbours. The topic touches the targets of "Europe 2020" - employment, education, poverty and social exclusion.  Of course the project is awaited with great interest. 
The results of the research made will be collected and  analyzed in teamwork.
European College of Business and Management
