The current sequa mobility programme allots 735 of 1050 slots to trainees as part of a pool that is open to individual applicants from all over Germany. Sequa is familiar with the quality criteria for the management of pool projects and applies them. The objective of sequa’s mobility programme is the improvement and internationalisation of vocational education within Europe. It supports the mobility of trainees and professionals in vocational education.

sequa is a non-profit organisation of the German private sector. Shareholders are Germany's top four business membership organisations BDA, BDI, DIHK, and ZDH as well as GIZ. sequa is a globally operating development organisation that has carried out projects and programmes of international cooperation in close collaboration with the German private sector since 1991. Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) and mobility of employees are part of the organisation’s main purposes and thus have  a high priority. sequa’s commitment to support vocational mobility already began in its year of foundation and was further developed throughout the years. From 1991 to 2017 sequa has carried out more than 2,600 mobility measures for apprentices, journeymen, skilled workers, and professionals in the TVET sector. Today, sequa implements the programme as leader of  a consortium of chambers, associations and companies. 

sequa, as the lead applicant, is responsible for the financial monitoring, the coordination and steering of the programme in close cooperation with its partners. The entire consortium is responsible for the implementation of the programme. Roles, responsibilities and quality standards for this cooperation are determined in the “Quality Manual sequa Mobility” which is based on the quality standards for pool projects published by NABIBB. Interested persons may apply either to sequa or to one of the consortium partners. Since 2012 the programme consists of three programme segments.

The target group for the programme segments SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL comprises trainees and young professionals. SINDBAD supports study trips of apprentices from all professions; the study trips are mostly group activities of three to four weeks. During their stay in a host company they get the opportunity to increase their professional knowledge and familiarize themselves with the working conditions in other European countries. The programme segment TRANSDUAL addresses trainees in commercial occupations and supports business language and competence training in France, the UK or Spain. The participants attend a seminar of three to four weeks that introduces the basics of the economic and legal system of the host country. 

SINDBAD and TRANSDUAL allow the participants to learn new techniques within their occupations in the host country, to increase their language skills and intercultural competences and thus, improve their competitiveness. Through the development of professional, methodical, and social competencies of the participants the programme segments contribute to the reduction of youth unemployment in Europe

Additionally, since 2012 sequa offers a programme segment for professionals in vocational education (e.g. teachers, instructors, trainers) of the consortium partners. move-it (mobility of vocational educational institutions and trainers) enables individual professionals in vocational education to exchange work experiences and techniques with other professionals abroad. The designs of the study trips can vary significantly, according to the needs, and give the participants the opportunity to get insights into European TVET structures, to increase their language and intercultural competencies and to develop their European network. The professionals will use their learning experiences abroad to enhance their teaching and the development of new training concepts. Furthermore, they may motivate their apprentices to become more open to working opportunities abroad, especially in Europe. 

Both target groups of sequa’s mobility programme are important multipliers in mobility, especially the professionals in vocational education. Open-minded TVET professionals and “mobile” trainees with experience abroad, who think and act with an international mindset, contribute to the intra-European recognition of learning experiences and support the harmonisation of European TVET systems. Furthermore, the mobility programme promotes the European Idea that says Europe is diversity and culture, friendship and togetherness, sustainability and future. Especially in politically challenging times, it is important that the EU understands itself not only as a purely economic community of purpose, but also and above all as a cultural and political community with shared values.
Background to British Business  / Bilaterale Entwicklung einer Wetterstation
European College of Business and Management

The two-year projects “Background to British Business” and “Bilateral Development of a Meteorological Station” aim to strengthen the quality of vocational education for teachers and pupils at the BSGZ through “work-based learning”. 
The following topics will be part of the project for educational staff and for learners:
- Learn about cross-cultural education
- Pedagogy and didactics
- International cooperation, international relations and common development

Exemplary goals 
For the organization:
- Professionalization of educational staff
- Internationalization as an important part of school development

For the learners:
- Increase of self-esteem
- Reduction of inhibitions against going abroad in a globalized world
- Development of foreign language skills

For the educational staff:
- Development of cross-cultural professional competence
- Improvement of tuition skills through experiences with foreign working methods
- Culture-sensitive handling of and empathy with learners and people with migration background
We are planning to dispatch 60 pupils from two different departments in four flows of 3 weeks each as well as six teachers of the BSGZ for one week each.

Activities for learners:
- Apprenticeship in foreign educational institutions
- Participation in classes
- Realization of a common international project
- Culture in the foreign countries
Activities for educational staff:
- Job Shadowing
- Culture in the foreign countries

The BSGZ works with ECVET instruments (e.g. Memorandum of Understanding, Learning Agreement, Europass Certificate) and ECVET principles (e.g. learning results and units of learning outcomes) to maintain the quality assurance of the projects and to promote transparency. Through ECVET we provide the recognition of the gained results and competences. The learners attend extra-curricular lessons to prepare them in every possible professional, pedagogic, intercultural and organizational way. The accompanying educational staff talk with the learners on a regular basis to monitor, reflect and discuss their professional and personal learning progress. 
Some participants are under age, so they will always be accompanied by teachers of the BSGZ.
There will be daily minutes to keep records about the learning progress. A portfolio of the stay abroad will reflect the whole experience abroad.


Project background:
English is a very important part of the curriculum for business management assistants and for industrial mechanics at vocational schools. Due to rising internationalization and globalization we see the need to qualify our students for these challenges. This is most efficient in an authentic surrounding where you can experience and acquire new skills in a direct way. Above all, trainees who have not had the opportunity of being supported, i.e. especially not through European exchange programs, should be enabled to profit from this project. This conforms to the basic principles of our school concept.
Project goals: 
The participants are expected to deepen both their general and business knowledge of English during the 3-week-course at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London. With the project-related work they shall be encouraged to work on their own, improve their presentation skills as well as develop team-spirit qualifications which are essential in a modern business world. The participants in Turin work in a bilateral team.
Moreover, we want the participants to improve their language competence and gain valuable intercultural experience, build up a healthy self-confidence and develop self-worthiness not only for their professional career.
The acquired competences will be reflected by the pupils and reviewed by the teachers at the end of the project with the “Assessment of Learning Outcomes”. The experiences of the participants will also be analyzed by the BSGZ as pupils fill out an evaluation sheet after coming back from England and Italy. The Memorandum of Understanding will be reflected after every flow.
All results of the different evaluations will be used to improve future projects.
The participants share their foreign experience within the school as well as in public events in order to open up the school in an international and intercultural way. There will be reports on the project in local events with the Chamber of Commerce and the companies as well as in the press and on the website of the school.
On the long run our school will be strengthened as a modern, international and intercultural partner in the German dual system, especially for business management assistants and for industrial mechanics. Erasmus+ helps us a lot and is also an essential part of gaining that goal.
European College of Business and Management

As the European mobility and the acquisition of transversal key competences during the vocational training are of high relevance, we want to extend the services of the Erasmus+ pool project EuroMobility and increase our contribute to the European networking. Many apprentices have shown their interest in undertaking an internship abroad. But they need appropriate support and guidance, especially as an own application to a mobility project is an obstacle for them and their companies. 
With this application we plan to enable a stay abroad for 90 apprentices, mainly from SMEs, within the next two years. The planned industry focuses of the project includ the areas of electrical, metal/ engine- and vehicle construction, services [esp. Hotel / catering, cleaning], logistics, business / management [esp. in the field of wholesale and foreign trade, retail, office] and care / health. These industries benefit especially from the European Economic Area and have concrete prospects of integration because of the impending shortage of skilled workers. The apprentices and their companies will be supported by qualified BWHW professionals. The apprentices can be sent individually for a four to six week internship in suitable foreign partner companies in order to gather new practical experiences, additional job related qualifications and personal as well as professional key skills. During that time the trainees should learn traditional work processes and develop their own mobility in the European job market as well. The planned stay abroad is an integral part of the vocational training. The work plan abroad is based upon the current occupation and is coordinated in advance with the training company, the vocational school and the relevant authorities. 
The BWHW offer a linguistic, educational, professional and intercultural preparation and with the current partners abroad will provide a full support and supervision for every step of the mobility.  Partners in countries such as France, Italy, Poland, Ireland, Spain and Great Britain are provided. The partners abroad are companies and business-related institutions, which will be able to provide suitable internship positions. Depending on demands new partners will be added to the pool.

The  “Berufskolleg Suedstadt“ in Cologne offers full-time or part-time training programmes to its trainees. Being one of the first European schools in North Rhine-Westphalia, it has always been aiming at enabling all its students the realization of an internship in other European countries. The educational programme “State-certified Commercial Assistants with Focus on Foreign Languages” had been acting as forerunner and was, thus, able to establish contacts and partnerships with business enterprises and schools in France, Great Britain, Spain, Malta and Cyprus in the past decades which every year provide placements to the applicants. This year, 41 trainees will realize an internship in the countries mentioned above as well as in Poland and Ireland. The internship lasting 8 or 11 weeks, respectively, serves as the practical application of the theoretically acquired knowledge during the vocational training. It takes place in its last year when students already have acquired very good knowledge in foreign languages and MS Office. The participants of the internship project carry out commercial correspondence, translate texts into the German language, create customers’ files, participate in customer acquisition, verify transport documents and carry out tasks of the front or back office in hotels. Five interns of the course of “Foreign Language Correspondence Clerks” will realise their 3-weeks-internship in Great Britain  towards the end of their second year of traineeship. For these students there also exists a pool of partner companies which annually take new interns or help them to find a placement in order to apply and broaden their language skills. Moreover, the internships serve to gain new insights into the practical work of an enterprise. As a consequence, the participants support the employees when doing their daily work and – depending on the respective branch – carry out tasks like the re-organisation of a clients’ file, the research of information about topics communicated beforehand or the assistance in an event’s organisation. 
Furthermore, this year 10 trainees of the vocational courses “Individual Insurance”, “Retailers” and “Personnel Service Providers” will do their 3-weeks-internship in European countries, frequently in subsidiaries of their employing company, where they are offered the opportunity to work quite goal-oriented taking into account probable cultural differences. For the first time, two students of the educational programme called “Commercial College” are aiming at a 2-weeks-internship abroad. Within the framework of the college’s strategy of internationalisation, it is planned to establish a pool of partner enterprises, too, in order to offer the possibility of taking part in the internship programme to even more students than those of the courses mentioned above. Without the financial support and the formal framework of the ERASMUS+, students of any of the college’s educational programmes could hardly realise an internship abroad. All participants firstly apply in writing for a scholarship with the respective colleague in charge. “Berufskolleg Suedstadt” has got an EU-Team which is led by a project coordinator. Two other colleagues are responsible for the financial processing and insurance matters. Additionally, in each educational programme there is a colleague who is familiar with its specific circumstances and supervises the trainees. Due to the high number of interns deriving from the “Assistants with Focus on Foreign Languages”, there is a colleague responsible for English-speaking EU-countries, Spain and France each, whereas singular internships in Poland this year and the like are cared for by the project coordinator. Once a general overview of the internship programme has been provided by the project coordinator, the teachers in charge draw a selection of the participants, prepare the internship itself, care for the students during their stay abroad and monitor the follow-up work after their return. This also comprises an intensive maintenance of the contact with partner institutions. Due to the possibility of job-shadowing, the personal mobilities in France, Great Britain and Malta predominantly serve the upgrading and broadening of content aspects, especially in foreign trade, customer communication and development of the vocational education in various European countries. Moreover, language skills are intensified and – if necessary – improved. The personal maintenance of the contacts with partnership firms enabled by these mobilities, is a vital factor of the project’s success and must not be underestimated. In order to take part in a personal mobility, the staff applies to the head of the college who - according to the qualification and demand – decides for the teacher to take part in the project. The results of the personal mobilities are communicated to the staff in team meetings, conferences of members of the same subject or educational programme and the students.
MY AIM III: Managing Yourself-  Achievement, Inspiration, Motivation
European College of Business and Management

In our recent projects MY AIM and MY AIM II/ OUR AIM the self-management approach has been implemented as an integral element of work placements abroad. Additionally, MY AIM II/ OUR AIM: „Managing Yourself and Organisational Units Restructured: Achievement, Inspiration, Motivation“ has broadened the perspective offering further education to educational staff in schools and companies in order to develop a wider European perspective in vocational training. Focusing our project on more target groups serves the organisational development of our school and our partners in a widening European/ global context. MY AIM III therefore follows a consistent development, continuing the approach of our first projects.
As a certified European School the Berufskolleg Mönchengladbach encourages and supports students in developing  a broad European perspective. Promoting mobility is especially emphasized. The new project MY AIM III is directed at trainees and VET students and aditionally focuses on training staff in schools and companies. We offer participants the possibility to do a work placement in another European country so that they can try out and put into practice their professional, linguistic and personal competences in new challenging contexts.
MY AIM combined central objectives promoted by the ERASMUS+-programme  -  lifelong  learning, further development of employability, internationalisation of professional education as well as recognition and certification of learning outcomes – with a self-management approach. The tools and instruments used in self-management (planning tools, setting objectives, feedback-analysis) are especially suited to develop and expand personal competences in the context of European work placements. The following project MY AIM/ OUR AIM  has aimed at implementing these objectives on all organisational levels: on the individual level of the trainee, on the organisational of the school itself, on the level of cooperations with our partner companies.
ECVET-principles (recognition of learning outcomes, identification of units of learning) and  ECVET-instruments are essential elements of the general project management as well as tools for managing the participants´ learning process.
The new follow-up project MY AIM III seeks to perpetuate this development.

The project MY AIM III will have a decisive influence on:
-  the internationalisation of vocational training concepts
 - the „Europeanisation“ of professional qualifications
- the participants´ abilities to organize and influence their professional development actively, autonomously and self-confidently and to discover broader perspectives regarding their professional mobility
- the cooperating companies to take into account not only purely professional skills, but to a larger extent personal competences 
- the Berufskolleg Volksgartenstraße to focus more on students´ individual competences and learning processes and to develop an even broader European perspective in professional education

The results of MY AIM will be presented to and made available for a broad public.
European College of Business and Management

As a background, the "Berufsschule II Kempten" is currently in the process of evaluating and updating its strategic direction. During this evaluation, an opportunity for growth regarding its international orientation was observed.  The increasing importance of international work experience as part of a successful future work profile is widely recognised. Based on this realisation the German Parliament decided in 2013, that the goal is to enable at least 10% of all apprentices to gain international work experience in some form.  The predominantly small and medium sized company landscape in the region of Kempten/Allgaeu, allows for rather limited opportunities for students to gather international experience e.g. in foreign subsidiaries. As a result, the BS II Kempten decided on integrating the “international orientation” into its set of targets. Concrete goal is to support more students, in cooperation with their employers, to gather international work experience.

After analysing the demand and defining the strategic goal, available resources to meet the targets were evaluated. As a key result, the main concern is the financial feasibility for the students. As a consequence, this application form was put together. With the financial support of the Erasmus+ programme for the apprentices, the vocational School Kempten II would be enabled to reinforce an international awareness within its organization by  establishing an annual mobility project and therefore support the Bundestagsbeschluss from 2013. By organizing this annual mobility the school  can realize its target of "international orientation". 

What exactly does that mean? The BS II Kempten is planning to introduce an annual student mobility activity for 22 students from the professions Bank, Industry, Logistics,  Wholesale and IT. Our partnering institution is the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) based in London. The ECBM is the educational academy of the German-British Chamber of industry and commerce. It already proofed to be extremely reliable and experienced, which supports our selection as a partnering institution. 

Every year the 22 participants of the mobility will take part in an especially designed 3-week “Professional Development Programme (PDP)”. Besides the in-depth examination of various topics in business, politics and society from a European and international perspective, the programme will touch on multiple functional and cross-functional topics. The housing of the students will be realized in guest families. Benefit of this is twofold; the students will dive deep into the British culture as well as significantly improve their language skills.
With the participation in the PDP the apprentices have the possibility to receive the KIC (Kaufmann International Certificate). This prestigious international qualification will be achieved by an oral and a written exam, as well as a dissertation. Additional requirement for this certificate is the graduation of the commercial apprenticeship in Germany. Furthermore all students will obtain the "Europass Mobility" as a record of the acquired competences. In combination with the "Europass CV" (which will already be created by the students in the project application process) these documents constitute the foundation for future application possibilities all over Europe. 

A multilevel application procedure is conducted for the selection of the participants. A specific preparation phase, the mentoring of the students in London and the reflexion phase at the end of the mobility project are further important components. Rounded up is the mobility by the ceremonial award of the "Europass Mobilität", where not only the participants but also the school management and administration, the staff and the cooperative companies will be invited. The realisation of the project is accompanied by a project management concept that helps to ensure the success of the project. Especially appropriate evaluation tools should support the continuous improvement process of further Mobilities. 

The expected impact of the project is multidimensional. The apprentices will not only achieve a substantial increase in different competences, but also experience a leap in their personality development. Taking part in an Erasmus+ Programme improves particularly self-confidence and proactivity in young adults. The mobility is also expected to have an impact on family, friends, school staff and the cooperative companies. By being involved in a mobility project, even if it is just in a passive way, people will be more aware of the importance of the European idea and the peaceful international cooperation. This project has the chance to make a continuing contribution to a more conscious international orientation of the "Berufsschule II Kempten".
Doing Business in an Englishspeaking Environment
European College of Business and Management

Context / Background
In the background of economic globalization, it is important, in addition to academically trained to grant also people in vocational training foreign experiences to meet the needs of the world of work and the labor market. An - albeit short – stay abroad within the framework of vocational training shows the mobility of participants, their outstanding commitment and their raising employability.
Objectives
Goals, in addition to improving foreign language skills and professional competence, are mainly promoting self-confidence and initiative as well as the development of tolerance to other cultures and peoples. The described objectives meet the needs of ECVET and will be documented with the europassMobility and europassLanguage. A not unimportant side effect is that with the “Kaufmann International Certificate (AHK)” another formal certificate, an in Germany acknowledged document, will be reached.

Participants Group
The participants are all in initial vocational training in the dual system, or have completed the dual VET recently successful. The participants are recruited primarily from the professions bank clerks and industrial management assistants. Besides, also achievement-weaker find consideration.

Activities
In addition to schooling and language support, find self-regulated learning, working on economic issues with presenting the results as well as excursions to be held in London’s City based companies. The participants are nominated by training companies, which enjoy an excellent reputation for practical vocational training, but who see a clear need to improve the language skills of their trainees and future employees. In addition, a cultural program is offered with mandatory and optional elements.

The flow is planned for the following period:
03 May until 23 May 2020

Intended results and impact
Measurable results in terms of the development of language competence should be able to be derived by the repeated self-evaluation by the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR). With the increasing knowledge of the language and foreign experience itself the participants will be prepared to move well in an unknown environment which increases employability as well as their future chances on the labor market. The sending training companies can be sure to find an attractive and up-to-date programme in order to attract more potential job trainees. The awareness of Europe will also be strengthened as well.
Professional International Training für Großhändler II
European College of Business and Management

Background and aims of the project:
This Erasmus-Project follows a request of the commercial department of our school from 2016.
This project started with the thoughts, to offer our wholesalers a contemporary, approved, job-related advanced training in an English-speaking environment.
The European College of Business and Commerce (ECBM) is located in the heart of the city of London with its international financial and commercial districts as the cultural sights.
It is an ideal starting point for everybody, who wants to collect experiences in the British, European and international business and cultural community.
The project is linked with our curriculum and the expectations of our companies.
Our main-target is to impart job-related, intercultural and linguistic skills to our participants in lessons and excursions.  This shall secure their chances on the international employment market. The involved companies are especially looking forward to the intense training program with the exams for the "international businessman" at the end of the project.

Number and profile of the participants:

At each flow there will be 20 apprentices participating from mainly medium-sized wholesaler-companies. Most of them take part in the project at the beginning of their second year at school. Some of them could already participate at exchange-programs in their former schools, but up to now, they had no chance to collect job-related experiences abroad.

Organization and implementation:

1. Preparation:

In the preparation we discuss with Sarah Iles (ECBM) the content of the course, adjust them with the curriculum and sign the contract with the ECBM (ECVET). We inform the companies, select the participants, determine the learning agreements (ECVET), organize the flights and the airport-transfer, conclude the insurances and prepare the participants intensively for their stay in London.

2. Project:
During the activity the ECBM will be responsible for transfers, selection of host families, the course-program, excursions and evaluations. The attending teacher will work closely with the teachers of the ECBM and secure the transfers of our students.
 
3. Post-processing:

In the post-processing the participants will evaluate the project and present their experiences to the other students and prospective participants. So we can ensure to go on with the project and to enrich the lessons in school. They write articles for the annual report at school and the local newspapers. Additionally we will complete their EUROPASS-documents. 


It is our main aim, to intensify the job-related knowledge and skills on an international way and to increase the linguistic skills of the participants, to encourage their willingness to achieve life-long learning and mobility.

According to the statements of the IHK companies are forced to raise their international activities in case of acquisition and sales.
The vocational skills of the employees should be prepared for this development.
Linguistic skills in English, the international language of commerce, and knowledge of typical economic structures of an important trading-partner will be a competitive advantage for our wholesalers.

Our aim is to continue and to intensify our cooperation with the ECBM. Each year shall 20 motivated apprentices take part in this project. For the involved teachers means the close cooperation with the ECBM a possibility to interchange information and ideas on an European level and to receive an insight to the global trading point London 
These experiences and perceptions will be enrich the normal vocational lessons in Germany.

The ECBM project is supposed to be a further part of our strategy to internationalize our school. We will - as we did it in earlier projects as Brigit-compass, Yeast and PROFIT I - work responsibly with the allocated support to broaden the benefit for our students.
Internationalisierung der Technikerausbildung in der Kunststofftechnik und Faserverbundtechnologie + Englisch Training für Berufsschüler
European College of Business and Management

As school for technical product design, the BSZ Wasserburg a. Inn would like to prepare its students for the upcomming work life in international organizations, acting in global markets.
20 students will be sent to ECBM in London to improve their knowledge in business english and for a multiplication at our local school.

The project with BMW UK with one student of the professional school for plastic engineering and carbon composites, will be a first checkup, if long term internships in european countries could be a permanent part of the education in our school.
Fachspezifischer Trainingskurs für kaufmännische Auszubildende in Großbritannien
European College of Business and Management

Due to the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of the working environment it has become more and more important in recent years to prepare the trainees for these challenges in their various jobs. Confident communication with foreign partners requires good knowledge in the world language English on the one hand and on the other hand also a high degree of intercultural competence. Our projects contribute to support our trainees especially in the above mentioned aspects which also corresponds to our school internal quality management understanding (“Schulinternes Qualitätsverständnis – SQV”). After having offered a language course for industrial clerk, bank clerk and office administration clerk trainees at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) in London for the past years we have now taken the decision to offer a practical training for retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees with B.I.G. Bristol. “Project 1” mentioned in this application form is the course at the ECBM, “Project 2” is the practical training with B.I.G. Bristol.

After getting in contact with the European College of Business and Management by the recommendation of another vocational school, various teachers of our school took part in a further education course at the ECBM. The experiences we gained there concretised the planning of an own project which was implemented the year after. Both the economic and pedagogic skills of the teachers at the ECBM concerning the transmission of central aspects of the British economy, culture and politics have convinced us to continue this project for more than ten years now.

The decision of offering another project (project 2) has prompted us to choose B.I.G. Bristol as a further partner organisation for retail clerk respectively wholesale clerk trainees. We got familiar with this company during a further education course about “Leonardo DaVinci”. B.I.G. Bristol organise practical trainings which meet the job requirements of our retail clerk and wholesale clerk trainees.

The main aim of project 1 is to enable 24 students from the vocational school "Staatliche Berufsschule II Memmingen" to attend a three-weeks course at the European College of Business and Management in London. The students, who train to be a bank clerk, industrial clerk or office clerk, are all in their second year of vocational training. During the course the students are able to improve their language skills in English as well as their knowledge in business administration issues.

At the college the students attend lessons every working day between 9.30 am and 4.45 pm. The lessons deal with topics which are related to their vocational training in Germany. The lessons are held by specially trained and experienced teachers from the college. In addition to the daily lessons, the participants have to write out an assignment on a special economic or social-economic topic, which is chosen by them individually. This as well as the final presentation at the end of the course, enhances the language skills immensely.

Concerning project 2, 20 wholesale and retail clerk trainees take part in a two-week internship in various commercial companies. They will get a close insight into the job-related practical experience and get the chance to interchange with their British colleagues. 

Next to the course, the students of both projects are obliged to plan and prepare several group excursions. The group leaders decide on relevant topics and talk them over with the students during the preparation meetings. The topics are then prepared in English by the student teams, so that they can be presented by them in London respectively Bristol and the surrounding area during the group excursions. 

Another major aim of the project is to enlarge the intercultural, social and individual skills of the students. They enter a new field with unknown cultural and social requirements, they learn to communicate and to cooperate with students and teachers. Both the projects in London and Bristol focus on the strategy of internationalisation and especially concentrate on an increase of mobility of the students, teachers and employers as well as the internationalisation of the “Berufsschule II Memmingen”.
Sviluppare le competenze per il turismo locale e della tradizione

"Improving traditional and local tourism skills - Tradition in Tourism" project has the aim of provide a training workexperience to 70 young people, to better get along with a new Tuscany Region Program and new tourism brand, namely "Costa di Toscana". This new tourist brand has been created to bring positive contribution to the specific area of Tuscany Region, but could be taken as a best practice for many other different interested regional areas.
Tourism is in a deep trasformation, to be alligned to the modern customer trends, who are looking for always new emotion e new way of travelling experience. People are searching for typicity and are willing to live specific culture and local traditions, from food to local and flokloristic events, traditional manufacturing and values.
Through this project's activities, participants could have a real workexperience of tourist systems  in which local products and tradition are values and attractions: They are included in tourism packages by all the companies from local tourism and catering sector.
Though is not enough culture, tradition or manufacturing and food product itself to guarantee a long term competitiveness about a specific tourism destination or place, It must be supported and promoted by all the tourist system and connected companies such as resturants, hotels, typical shops and so on. Such a tourist system will be able to deliver a wide range of services and experiences related to the culture and tradition, a brand of local identity, really new, innovative and attractive. 
Participants could have their own workexperience (as in the field of reception, customer care and tourist pack promotion, as in the field of food and catering) within a tourist integrated system that has been able to offering attractions, food and events connected to the local area, culture and traditions: a real tourism identity.

Main aims of the project are: developing skills for innovative tourism; improving foreign language skills; realizing a model of recognition for skills credits to facilitate moving from education paths to vocational training and to the labour market so far; working out a guidelines manual about how to aknowledge skills from non formal paths and how to certify those skills.

The project consortium is made by 5 European Partners, each of them with strong relationships with hotel, food and catering sector entrepreneurs. Eu countries involved have specific local and regional tourist attractions, so that participants could find real interesting and innovative work experiences about typicity and traditional tourism. Consortium Partners will sign and approve specific agreements and rules about L.O. with the Memorandum of Understanding. Besides there will be a L.A. in which all the skills and knowledge will be confirmed by all the organizations involved in the workexperience and by the participant itself.

Project's mobilities actions will be addressed to 2 different target groups:
Group1-4 weeks mobility:, students, attending the forth year of voctional secondary school in food and catering sector 
Group2-12 weeks mobility: new graduates (within 1 year from graduation exam) with priority to those in food and catering sector. Host companies could be: restaurants of typical dishes, agrotourisms, organic farms, experts in traditional food and manufacturing products. Receptions of hotels with a particular attention to tourism packs about traditional and flokloristic events, integrating local products and culture with tourism. Hotels operators should know well the area to promote events and culture, offering personalized packages to their customers.

Coming back from this mobility experience both the groups will have improved their vocational, cultural and language skills, their transversal skills such as communication, self esteem, intercultural relationships. Staff involved in the project's activities will have increased their skills too, in particular will have developed skills about managing european networks and procedures on how to aknowledge and certify skills in terms of EQF, using ECVET method and tools.
The final event with tourism operators and companies, PES functionaries, companies associations will have a long term diffusion of an innovative model for workexperiences in traditional and local identity tourism. This will bring a wind of change in policies related to voacational training, education and working world.
Ciudad de los Muchachos avanza hacia Europa

“Ciudad de los Muchachos” is a Salesian vocational training institution. Our institution is located in the Madrid district of Puente de Vallecas, who suffers from negative socio-economic circumstances in a high percentage of its population. The center welcomes children of families in the area and surroundings, who are workers, many of them immigrants, humble and often hit by unemployment.

The project is born from the need to give a development opportunity for our students whose circumstances do not compete on equal terms students from other areas,and who do not know the opportunities granted by the EU's free movement of workers.

It is not the first time that we implement European programs. We took in 2013 and 2014 Leonardo da Vinci project (2012-1-ES1-LEO01-51313) into two streams, and currently we have participated in three national consortiums (2014 -1-ES01-KA102-002276, 2015-1-ES01-KA102-014483 and 2016-2-ES01-KA102-035156) with the Inform Foundation. The Inform Foundation was the coordinator for foreign companies to allocate and transfer of our administration students. In 2016 and 2017, we finished our second and third individual projects, in this case the project 2015-1-ES01-KA102-014431 and 2016-1-ES01-KA102-024322. Finally, in 2018, we are implementing our fourth individual project 2017-1-ES01-KA102-035915. 

In this project we want to do 13 allocations, 6 for basic FP and 7 to Intermediate. Their stay would last 32 days for the first group, and 92 days for the second group. For intermediate VET students, it will happen from the third week of March, 2019, and from the second week after Easter, 2018, for the Basic VET students.

All students belong to the electrical, automotive, IT and administration fields.

In both cases, they are students, in large percentage, who did not complete their compulsory secondary education, and very often, they present complex and difficult family situations like low self-esteem, truancy and behavioral problems.

Thanks to these programs many of them they get back on track in the education system, and then, they develop all their personal, social and professional shortcomings. These programs open their horizon and convince them that your life is not doomed to failure.

We will do two types of activities.

For Basic Vocational Training, students will go in a training center to Fossano (Italy), at the school, "Maria Ausiliatrice", it belongs to the network of FP CNOS-FAP. The idea is that they perform Compulsory FCT in an atmosphere of real work to finish their studies and graduate. The students will be integrated as center workers and will develop skills acquired in Spain and the linguistic competence in Italian.

For Intermediate Vocational Training, students will go in internship companies to Pistoia (Italy) and Dublin and London, by means of CSCS, Zero Negativo, MicroPro and KCC, which are our hosting partners. They are going to have the first work experience, developing autonomously their professional and personal duties. In this way, they are going to develop their professional and social skills, Italian and English language skills and personal autonomy. 

The methodology used to implement the project has a team of 5 people for this, which are the principal headmaster, the Educational director, administrator, a bilingual English teacher and coordinator Erasmus + designated to fulfill all management tasks.

The methodology is to implement a set of requirements to meet the objectives set according to the needs, the learning outcomes which aims to observe,  the implementation of a plan to disseminate the projected Erasmus + program, a  selection process of students, a study of the project impact on our institution and students and an evaluation of the results.

The expected impact is a consequence of the results that are expected. We expect to achieve our institution to become a reference center of the area in which the supply of European programs. This is one of our hallmarks, that will attract new students. We want through these programs our students, directly and indirectly, may access to opportunities for professional, social and personal improvement that they enjoyed in the past.

In one hand, it is expected that the center is an attractive partner to receive staff and students from abroad. So, the improvement of facilities, faculty and teaching methodology is a must. In the other hand, the students should acquire self-esteem, autonomy and responsibility.

Our students will improve their academic performance, and they will become the best means to transmit the best practices from the center, and its commitment to European programs, As a result from this, it will improve their employability. It is therefore expected that the center has increased enrollments and offer training courses. Center should have an even greater commitment to new European programs, and become transmitter of good practice among other centers of Madrid and Europe.
Improve Upon employment opportunities to VET students in Europe

Due to the digitalization and technological progress of the labor market, the high rates of youth unemployment in Spain and the large number of students who drop out of school without professional qualification, the consortium's of VETschool are aware to face the challenge of improving the professional development of  VET students  for their participation as active citizens in society and to improve their opportunities to join the European labor market.

The project aims at providing VET students with the chance to deepen and improve the quality of their training, by carrying out internships in European companies, and getting in contact with European labour market. 

The good results and the close cooperation among the VET Schools that are members of the consortium, set the basis for the development of this project.The consortium is composed by 8 VET schools of the Valencian Region, coordinated by the IES Lluis Simarro.

The VET schools consortim needs to establish European quality networks with companies and other educational centres throughout Europe, in order to stay update on innovations, to share good practices and to get informed on European policies, improving the quality of the provided teaching and trainings, thus fighting youth unemployment.

The project is adressed to 84 students and former students who are attending the 2nd course of school-based intermediate VET programme of IT, construction and civil engineering, electronics and electricity, hospitality and tourism and administration or graduates in the last year: mid-level technicians of these specialties. All the institutes will select 10 students (2 former students and 8 students), except the CIPFP Xeste and the IES LLuis Simarro who will select 12, two of them will be ErasmusPro

It is worth mentioning that relations with Istituto Elsa Morante in Italy  fostered reciprocity, it has also submitted a mobility project in which Spanish consortium will receive their students. The reciprocity will enhance the promotion of the European active citizenship.
The 14 monts project will last from the 1st of June 2018 to the 30th of July 2019. The internship will be carried out from the 10th of March to the  30th of June 2019.  
The following activities will be structured in 5 phases:
E1- Activities for communicating and spreading information to promote the students’ participation, planning tasks (including participants’ selection), establishing Learning Agreements, reviewing of ECVET documents, logistics and organization (insurance, lights and accommodation), determining contract-related issues, selecting hosting companies, tutors and accompanying teachers, setting up a common dissemination plan.
E2-Preparation of the mobilities. Information Meeting, signing contracts, cultural and professional preparation, OLS language courses.
E3- Implementation of mobilities. Follow-up, evaluation and certification of participants. Competences will be determined in the Learning Agreement and will be evaluated, using the ECVET instruments and will be certifies by Europass. 
E4- Quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the overall project’s results.
E5- Dissemination. The dissemination activities will be carried out during all the project
In addition to the impact on the participants, the project will also benefit all the partners, by fostering  European cooperation and the relationships between companies and educational centres. 
Both dissemination activities and the mobility experience itself will produce an impact at local, regional and national level. 
Other local, regional and national entities will be able to to benefit from the project’s results (even though they are not partners of the project):
- Creation of a quality network that include educational centres and companies
- Decrease in youth unemployment rate
- Improvement of youth qualifications
- Increase in VET enrolment 
- Creation of new collaborative networks at regional level
- Widening the possibility of internationalization for other centres, and their chance to be part to other European projects
- Better knowledge of the Erasmus+ programme and EU values (tolerance, equity, equality and inclusion).
- Fostering the sense of European active citizenship and respect of other cultures
- Possibility to create new companies and new business models 
- Promotion of social inclusion
The project is in accordance with the 2020 strategy, with the 20 principles of the European Pillar of social rights, with the goals of Erasmus + to improve the professional development of  VET students, their participation as active citizens in society and their employability inside and outside the European Labour market
Patways for upskilling students in Europe

The project responds to the need that VET schools have to provide their students with the chance to increase and improve the quality of vocational training, by taking internships in European companies, and getting in contact with the single European labour market.

The success of the collaboration in the previous consortium integrated by 9 Public VET schools of the Valencian Region and promoted by the IES Ramón Esteve, the high rate of insertion of the students to the labor market (90%), the great interest and the satisfaction of the students and the coordinators who participated in the previous project, as well as the close and fluid collaboration of the VET schools involved in the consortium, have fostered the present project that it will satisfy the demands of the VET schools makes possible the collaboration with enterprises at national  and European level. The dissemination actions of the results have made possible the incorporation of 2 VET schools more.

The project integrated by 11 VET schools in Valencian Region is adressed to 77 VET students and former students who are doing the 2nd year of the cycles of intermediate level in informatics and communications, agrarian and administration; or graduates in the last year: medium-level technicians from these specialties. The project foresees 8 monthly flows (4 to Italy, 1 to Portugal, 1 to Brussels, 1 to Latvia and 3 to UK) and 2 Erasmus Pro flows of three months (1 to Italy and 1 to UK) Each VET schoolwill select 2 former students and 5 students, one of them Erasmus Pro. There are 5 flows to Italy and 3 to the UK because the profile of the partners as well as the different geographical areas of them will enable the students to carry out their work. training in different fields since companies, even if they are from the same sectors, are very different.

The main OBJECTIVE of the project is:
To allow VET students to develop, through training practices in European companies, the skills and abilities to complete, in a practical way, the skills acquired in VET to be incorporated efficiently into the  European labor market, either on account own or for others. To do this, VET students needs to develop specific tecnical skills on the specialty that they has studied, but transversal, social and intercultural skills will also be necessary to face new challenges and become active citizens with values for the future.

The main ACTIVITIES  will be carried out are:
- PREPARATION of the motilities: selection of the participants, initial evaluation of their competences, pre-departure training of participants, logistics and agreements’ tasks definition, coordination, etc.
- IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MOBILITY. Implementing the internship programs in the companies. The mobility also includes cultural activities.
- EVALUATION OF THE PARTICIPANTS. The competences that will be acquired during the stay abroad will be evaluated according to the ECVET system and will be previously set, during the initial evaluation. All the internship activities will be planned to achieve these competences and will be customized.
- MONITORING. The development of the internships will be monitored by all the tools and processes, previously agreed by the project.
- EVALUATION OF THE PROJECT. 
- DISSEMINATION. The dissemination activities will be carried out in all project’s phases. A final conference for the dissemination of the project’s results will be organized. Besides the impact on the participants, the project will benefit all partners, fostering the European cooperation and relationships between companies and educational centres.

The DISSEMINATION activities and the mobility itself will generate an IMPACT at local, regional and national level. 

The IMPACT of the project will be:
The project will improve the opportunities for VET students to be actively incorporate national or European labor market, either on their own account or as an employee, in a more effective way
The collaboration between the participating organizations will allow promoting European cooperation and internationalization and it will make it possible to bring companies closer to VET schools and it will improve too the collaboration with other VET schools, public authotities, etc. It will give participating entities a vision about most demanded professional profiles and the skills that students must learn

The project is directly linked to the 2020 strategy, the skills agenda and the European priorities  to help the EU and its Member States generate a higher level of employment, productivity ,social cohesion and development.
Small Business Clubs for socially fragile target groups

The project: "Small Business Clubs for socially fragile target groups" as the European Development Plan of the AdMERITUM Foundation for 2018-2019, is part of our organization's activity - mentoring, educational staff of the foundation, mentoring program for leaders - so-called "Leaders of change", cooperating with the foundation of volunteers from all over Poland. Leaders conduct educational activities in the form of "Small Business Clubs" in the field of entrepreneurship for local communities of entrepreneurs and future entrepreneurs, including people with motor and mental disabilities, so-called NEETs - people permanently unemployed, not participating in training and education, migrants, both immigrants from outside the EU and migrants within the EU, as well as elderly people aged 50+, as well as women from small villages. Educational activities are designed to encourage participants (target group) to enter into life on the path of entrepreneurship, which will allow to overcome the impasse in which they found themselves in their personal and professional life (these two spheres overlap and affect one another).

By implementing this project, we want to improve the quality of work of leaders and mentors themselves through participation in improvement courses at foreign partners, in order to work more effectively at the local level and include the European aspect in the clubs' activities.
The quality of educational activities for the target group at the local level will be increased by the acquisition and increasing by the educators (project participants) of the competences identified as necessary to improve, in the areas of:
- developing leadership skills in relation to educational work with a vulnerable target group of people at risk of exclusion from the community due to unemployment, inactivity, age, social status (women in small village communities)
- development conflict management skills in educational work with the target group
- increasing ICT skills to integrate the ICT tool into the educational process in working with the target group.

The quality of educational activities for the target group at the European level will be made possible thanks to the improvement of English language skills by the educators (project participants) and will be introduced thanks to establishing partnerships with partner institutions in this project, from which the educators will learn, drawing on their know-how and experience in educational work with similar target groups. Establishing partnerships will also allow the introduction of entrepreneurship education for the target group through the exchange of knowledge and experience at the European level - to organize international meetings of club participants to establish contacts, exchange knowledge and good practices.
Another area of internationalization of activities that will be possible to develop thanks to this project will be
organizing job shadowing and study visits for educators from other countries interested in establishing cooperation and implementing similar practices in their countries.
Das PDP-Programm: eine berufliche Zusatzqualifikation zur Verbesserung der interkulturellen Kompetenz und der Internationalisierung der dualen Ausbildung
European College of Business and Management

The emphasis of our current project is on the transition from vocational training to employment and its requirements and challenges. To collect information, data and experiences our students are doing internships in the following three countries: Poland, Finland and Spain. 

Additionally a group of students took part in a professional development course (PDP programme) at the European College for Business and Management (ECBM) in London. The business courses are being taught in English and focus on international business and finance, but also Business English and international competences. After completing the PDP course the students can apply for the Kaufmann/-frau International Certificate (KIC). It will be awarded by the German-British Chamber of Industry and Commerce (AHK London), which operates under the umbrella of the German Association of Chambers of Industry and Commerce (Deutscher Industrie- und Handelskammertag, DIHK Berlin). Certificate holders prove that they are able to operate in an international business environment. As the programme was very successful, we would like to send further groups within the next years.

Beside our positive experiences and our well working cooperation the main reasons are:
- deepening the existing knowledge on business topics
- enhancing the knowledge by international aspects and points of view
- practice and improvement of English skills
- learning about business correspondance and intercultural awareness
- broadening of the vocabulary basis (especially concerning technical terms and expressions) - many of the students have chosen  bilingual lessons and are being taught "sales and marketing" in English. Since the courses at the ECBM are mainly about the topic "marketing" it is a great complement to the lessons at the vocational school in Germany
- getting to know the British culture and also other cultures while living with host families
- gaining of a more open-minded and more international point of view
- providing the students with the professional and personal qualifications, skills and knowledge necessary for being able to compete on the international job market in a further together growing Europe

Additionally we would like to send 6 teachers on a one week training course to London. The teachers are going to take part in business and business language modules at the European College of Business and Management (ECBM) and will visit the international trade fair "London Bike Show". The reasons behind this visit are: one major topic of the English curriculum of year 11 is the topic "trade fairs". Therefore the teachers get an practical insight into the topic. Another reason is that our vocational school works with a sample company producing bikes. In order to prepare authentic materials for the students and to be able to provide them with the correct tecnical terms and examples which are practice-realted it is important to have contact with bicycle manufacturers and distributers.  Therefor this training course is especially important for the English and CLIL/bilingual teachers of our school. The courses at the ECBM about marketing, sales and business correspondance will round off the programme. 

To sum up our plans the project will underline and support the internationalisation of our school and of our students and it rounds off our programme of work experiences abroad, international certificates and bilingual lessons.
Spedition, Großhandel, Industrie, Büromanagement in Europa
European College of Business and Management

We continue to organize and implement our most successful projects, we have been doing since 2012, but we are striving to add more projects with different countries and areas to boost the process of internationalisation at our school and region.
What we have been doing so far includes the following projects:

1. a,This is a learning stay of three weeeks in GB for apprentices at our partner college the "European College of Business &     Management". The participants come from all different departments of our college which is a pure business and commercial college.      is not an exchange program. We go there for learning purposes and get certificates of the AHK at the end and the title of "Kaufmann International".
The project is run in two flows:
1st flow: 14.05.17 - 03.06.17
2nd flow: 03.06.18 - 23.06.18

1st flow: 19.05.19 - 08.06.19
2nd flow: 10.05.20 - 30.05.20
   b,  Aim of the project:
        Participants are expected to improve their professional, linguistic, cultural skills.

2. There is a learning program with our partner institution in Spain (Vic)  for 16 apprentices which takes place yearly. It is especially for freight forwarding, wholesale and industrial clerks. In the ongoing year the financial European support has already been granted till 2019. The flow will take place for the 5th time.

3. There are 2 apprentices who are doing an additional 2-weeks placement with Schenker in Barcelona. It supplements the course mentioned in No.2.

4. In March 2018 we organize a teacher training course for 16 teachers of our school. This is a training programme for our coleagues who are also teaching English at our institution. It will take place in the "European College of Business & Management" in London and will last for a week A visit is planned to the MidKent College in Kent and we hope that the colleagues can study  the vocational educational  training and apprenticeship of our neighbour country and ameliorate the knowledge about GB. They should also imprive their linguistic competences and get new ideas for didactic methods. We would like to repeat and implement this program and so we apply again for funding to do another flow in the academic year 2019/2020. We also intend to invite colleagues of other schools as well.

For the oncoming year we are planning new projects:

5.We will go to Northern Ireland to Derry with 16 of our colleagues and we will visit the NorthWest Regional Col. in Derry. We hope that there will develop an exchange programme done with techers as lond as this will be possible under the white elephant of Brexit. Northernirish colleagues are kindly invited to come to our school and also visit companies in our area to get to know and learn more about our dual system.

6. However, we also intend to create a new program for students of our office management department. They should attend school there as well as attending companies to see and to get to know different styles of vocational learning. We do apply for 2 flows - 1 in each year - for a number of 10 students each year. Up to now office management has always been a group which did not participate in any European programs and we would like to change this and integrate them as well and offer them possibilities to experience other cultures and get to know other traditions. We very much hope that we also will be able to host students from the NWRC to create a real exchange of students.

7. We were lucky to find another new partner in the Netherlands in Alkmaar, the Horizon College. 9 teachers, 7 from our college BS4 and 2 from our neighbouring college 5 are going to Alkmaar in October to prepare a students´programme together with our partner colleagues. We intend to work out special modules where we can teach the group coming from 2 different countries a common topic which is valuable for both of them. This could be done in the frame of ECVET.

8.5 apprentices from sales executive will be going to the netherlands to do a three-weeks internship in the Netherlands. Our institution is already hosting 2 students from the Netherlands to help them finding placements in our companies of freight forwarding. Sending apprentices abroad to fulfil placements is new for our school. We haven´t done this before as companies in the dual system are always reluctant to release staff to be abroad over a longer period of time. However, times have changed in favour of us and more and more enterprises seem to support a three weeks stay abroad. Our partner in the Netherl. is extremely reliable and we are convinced that our program will be successful and it will be expandable and developable.

Up to now we were lucky to win and add new partnerships and we experienced a high amount of support in doing this. We have started EU-mobility programs six years ago and are developping slowly into a sort of hub and we will involve other vocational colleges in the region  via our own programs  or by giving them advise how to launch new European mobility programs
Doing Business in the English-Speaking World
European College of Business and Management

The majority of young people in Germany are trained in a scheme which is called „dual system". During their training they are employed by companies which train them on the job. On one or two days of the week the young people, who are apprentices, attend a vocational school. They are eligible to be trained in order to get those skills required for a career in the envisioned business or trade. This implies to acquire English language proficiency on the job. Expecially industrial companies, logistics firms and companies in the whole sale trade need employees with these skills. Companies and employers need that type of personnel
functioning effectively in a crosscultural environment. Our vocational school (bsnu) cannot transfer those skills completely as the curriculum only provides 45 minutes per week to train our students in English language and cross-cultural skills. According to academic studies native speakers of English can teach students, who learn English as a foreign language, more efficiently than indigenous teachers. This course aims at improving our students' professional competency as well as British culture and doing business in the United Kingdom. The course is designed for 24 participants. We will only take apprentices who attend our school and work in companies which provide business orientated training in professions like industrial clerks, logistics clerks or wholesale clerks. Sometimes we have applicants from the retail trade or students who are trained in managing warehouses. The majority of our students have an intermediate level of education. Only a small number of students have A-levels. Applying for our Erasmus+ project does not require A-levels. We recommend applying for participating in an Erasmus+ project of our school in the first or second year of their training because going to London in their final year may distract some students from preparing well for their final exams carried out by a German chamber of commerce and industry. A group of bsnu teachers and Ms Sarah lles of ECBM designed a concept and procedures for new Erasmus+ projects. We inform our students about new projects by handing out flyers and leaflets. We also put information about the projects on the bsnu website. Our teachers inform their students in the classrooms about our planned activities. We will send letters to companies which employ and train apprentices to provide information about the project. When apprentices apply for participating in our projects they must provide a written statement of their company showing they agree that their apprentice will be in London for three weeks during their regular period of vocational training. After evaluating the application forms we will choose the participants. lf a company indicates their apprentices require English and cross-cultural skills on the job in an extensive manner, those applicants will be put on a priority list. The advices and recommendations of the remaining companies and of teachers from our school, who teach those applicants, will also be considered when choosing participants. In future we will not provide any English language courses for the participants. They have to use online courses provided by Erasmus+ to improve their English proficiency. However, we will go on providing cross-cultural training and a specific training for the ECBM course in London. We will only send one group of twentyfour students to London per year. A female und a male teacher from our school will accompany the group when travelling to London. They will stay with the group in London for three weeks and will join the students on their journey back to Germany. The accompanying persons will monitor the group and their learning achievements. Ms Sarah lles and the ECBM lecturers will be in charge of the teaching and motivation of the group while the students are trained in London. After three weeks in London the participants can show in a presentation and in a written exam what they have learned. After returning from London to Germany, the participants will have to write an executive summary in English (1000 words) about the topics which they presented as a Microsoft PowerPoint presentation at ECBM. Our school will collect the participants' documents and pass them on to ECBM in London. 

Unfortunately a majority of British people voted that Great Britain should leave the European Union (Brexit). As we focused our international activities on the UK, we assume that after Brexit in a couple of  years there will be no EU-funded mobility projects with the UK as country of destination. We are searching for new partners and networks in lreland and Malta.

According to the guidelines of our school EU Internationalisation Strategy, this project is the follow up of FEELFUSION project and has as its main goal to train professionals with transversal skills for employment with an entrepreneurial and flexible attitude to meet trends of the labour market and to face the present crisis, unemployment and lack of specific skills. Entrepreneurship meant as a basic skill is the leit motif of our strategic plan and it will be the goal of the whole plan of activities. Other objectives are:
- offering quality and variety to our teaching offer; offering job opportunities; orienteering to career; improving a sense of European and global identity; promoting innovation at school; improving linguistic competences to overcome linguistic and cultural borders; promoting mobility in Europe and in the world and allow success into the more and more fast-moving and demanding job market   
- creating an updated learning environment to enable self-discovery and fulfilment, to create interest and awareness implementing CLIL methodologies; implementing a EU dimension in the school curricola and of the credit transfer system like  ECVET e EUROPASS
- developing competences and skills in using new media in students and staff to fill in the gap between the teachers' and the digital natives' worlds, by creating a common language; facilitating learning with diversified paths, overcoming borders and obstacles.
According to the VET Mobility Chart, the number of  beneficiaries will be 60 students attending the 4-5 class (catering, tourism, administration and marketing) and recent graduates of our school. The group includes disables, disadvantaged students and with learning difficulties. First learners will improve their competences in foreign language used abroad and will attend a pedagogic/professional training; after they will do a 4-week work placement to develop their field competences with a focus on fusion food and catering/tourism trends and social marketing. We will take advantage of ErasmusPro to offer 3-month mobilities to 2 recent graduates to give added value, develop job specific skills thus boosting their employability.   
Given the large number of mobilities, they will be no more restricted to excellence but offered in a systematic way to all students with good behaviour, increasing motivation and promoting school success as planned in our school mission. Our school will gain an international dimension and will convey good practises in the area. 
Students will be accompanied by 1teacher given the large number of minors and disadvantaged students+ 1 extra for fluxes with  students with special needs.  
The staff mobilities will be 25 (management and school staff) to offer wider opportunities to develop competences, overcome disaffection and spread passion for teaching. The mobilities will be concentrated on jobshadowing, workshops, courses about foreign languages,  new teaching tecHniques, CLIL and exchange of good practises.
On the return, the students will organise an event to put into practise the new skills gained: the cooking team will prepare fusion dishes, the bar/service team will serve fusion cocktails and arrange new setting up,  the hospitality team will think about a suitable welcoming while the marketing staff will plan a marketing campaign to launch the event on the social media. The guests will be local authorities and representatives of local associations to give visibility to the project. The staff  will spread the new methodologies learnt in their department and in the whole school and will put into practice their new skills in their classes. Everybody will  update learning paths and will spread an international dimension at school, a dynamic, motivating climate to get success and personal fulfilment
According to the internationalisation process, the network has been reinforced: we have chosen to keep the partners we trust and that are located in strategic markets  as well as to keep the prestigious cooperation we have with overseas partners, especially due to the project topic. We have added 3 prestigious partners: a 5-star hotel a London icon, a starred restaurant in Copenaghen and a refined restaurant in the heart of London.
Indeed we believe that training should be opened to an international market to mirror the multicultural, global composition of our society. These partners give added value to our project and will let learners widen opportunities and perspectives and will offer unique trainings in destinations that are among the top-world and in luxury accommodation like the 5-star holiday resort in Turks and Caicos and Lagham Hotel.  Besides they will allow job shadowing, exchange of good practise to the staff with high quality schools/companies in the world.  The mobilities will be at some partners but all the network will cooperate in the project's dissemination and success.
We will offer mobilities in the various foreign languages studied in our school.
Pameistrystė ir įgūdžių tobulinimas darbo vietoje

The aims of the project as well as foreseen activities meet our school‘s transnational strategy and tasks.
The activities based on Klaipeda Tourism School‘s transnational strategy are following:
 1. Further initiation and implementation of international projects, encouragement of co-operation between companies and our school, providing teachers and students with opportunities to take over technological innovations, putting emphasis on multiculturalism.
2. Our students, teachers and administration will be provided with opportunities to participate in exchange programmes and professional mastery contests. 
3. The school will be an active host organisation for students and teachers who participate in Erasmus+ based projects.  
4. Co-operation with business company is of great importance. Foreign specialists of various professions will be invited to give lectures at school.
5. Participation in international mastery contests will be continued.  
6. There will be co-operation with partners from Denmark, the Netherlands, The United Kingdom and Southern Europe. 
7. Mentorship and quality of the projects are to be intensified.
8. Vocational teachers and school workers will be able to improve their knowledge of the English language. 
 
46 students and 26 teachers/staff are planned to be sent to participate in practical training. 1 visit from Italy to give a lectures is due in 2018. 
Our school is reconsidering its partners‘ circle, some visits to the Netherlands, Denmark, Portugal have been planned. The school‘s aim is a more intensive co-operation with other vocational schools. ECVET application elements are being co-ordinated with host partners, a higher students‘ skill recognition is to be achieved.  
According to a partial transnational strategy, students will be sent to participate in practical training. The professions are following: cook, waiter/bartender, confectioner, recreation services agent. The students of the mentioned professions will visit: Spain, 7 students at a time (2 flows); 8 students will visit the United Kingdom, 4 students at a time (2 flows); 7 students, studying cooking and confectionery, will visit Italy, 5 confectioners will visit Denmark, 4 cooks, waiters/bartenders/confectioners will visit the Netherlands, 6 students, will visit Portugal. Accompanying teachers will be supervising students during the first week of the visit and will solve any problems related to the programme, accommodation, catering or local transportation. Long-distance journeys with changes have been planned. 
Two Erasmus PRO-long term mobilities are planned, two participants (cooks) will go to United Kingdom to work in a restaurant for 3 month period.
Recognition of academic achievements: host partners will define academic results applying ECVET elements. Once students are back to school, the results will be transferred to their journal, part of the practical training will be credited according to topics set in advance by vocational teachers, host organisation and participant. 
The following ECVET  elements will be used: an agreement and signing the Mutual Understanding Memorandum with partners is to be achieved. Practical training agreements will be signed by three parties, i.e. sending organisation, host organisation and participant. 
Teachers will visit the Netherlands, Spain, the United Kingdom and Portugal. Teachers are interested in getting more information about apprenticeship and developing their skills as these things are related to needs of  school, labour market in Lithuania. Participants will visit vocational schools which have similar training programmes alongside companies which accept apprentices and provide on-the-job training. Colleagues‘ work, organisation of practical training , evaluation/self-evaluation papers, supervision of apprentices will be observed and discussed.  Vocational teachers and school representatives will get acquainted with education system, organisation of practical training at school and companies, the forms of apprenticeship. These visits will be considered as professional development, teachers will be asked to describe the impact and present innovations to school‘s community.  
According to the strategy, our school aims to help vocational teachers improve the knowledge of foreign languages. Up to 20 teachers will attend English course in 2018.
The effect of the project is that vocational teachers will develop their professional skills, refresh teaching content, share their experience, organise mastery contests. The school‘s staff and administration will apply certain forms of apprenticeship, make changes in teaching programmes. They will also improve  management, organisational and language skills.
